div.p: ARCANA MOOREANA; OR, A Succinct and Lucid DISCOURSE, OF THE Origine, Eſſence, Scituation Symptoms, Cauſes and Cure OF THE CHOLICK, In all its various Denominations, different Kinds, Degrees, and Complications.

Done by Mr. John Moore, Apothecary, at the Peſtle and Mortar, in Abchurch-Lane, near
• umbard-ſtreet.

q.hi: Natura legibus eſſe Medicinae Leges conſentaneas, Medicus Remedia con • ert, non ſolum naturae Miniſter, Sed interdum ut Opifex primarius.

div.p: LONDON: Printed for the A •• hor. 1713.

div.head: THE Epiſtle Dedicatory. TO THE Right Reverend Father in GOD, Dr. John Moore, Lord Biſhop of ELY.
div.p:
AN indiſpenſible Neceſſity, obliging me to vindicate my Reputation in the Knowledge and Practiſe of Phyſick, againſt the Malicious Calumnies and Detractions of my Enemies; who
are only thoſe of my own Profeſſion, and ſuch as are unwarily prejudic'd by their Falſe and Scandalous Inſinuations; I hope I ſhall not be charg'd either with Vanity or Raſhneſs in Publiſhing theſe brief Eſſays; which are deſign'd for no other end, but that by reading this little Mannual, thoſe that are Strangers to my Perſon, may be convinc'd, that in Studying Phyſick, I have followed ſuch Learned Guides and Patterns, by whoſe Directions and Examples, and my own Experience, joined with a tolerable Capacity, and an indefatigable Induſtry and Diligence, that I am legally qualified for the Exerciſe of the Art I profeſs, maugre the inveterate Malice of all Oppoſers.

My Lord, My Life and Converſation, I bleſs God, being unattackable, even by Envy it
ſelf, and ſo being no Reproach to the Name I have the Honour to bear: And your Lordſhip being Celebrated for your Exemplary Piety, Charity, and profound Knowledge in Phyſick, as well as in all other Learned and uſeful Arts and Sciences, and conſequently a Proper and Sufficient Judge, of the Contents of the following Treatiſe.

I have humbly preſum'd to Dedicate it to your good Lordſhip, in great Sincerity, but in very plain Language; for if Nature had been more kind and liberal to me in Eloquent and Rhetorical Expreſſions, I durſt not have uſed them to your Lordſhip, who takes more Delight in doing good to others, than in reading deſerved Panegyricks on your ſelf.

And therefore if your Lordſhip is pleas'd to Pardon or Excuſe my Confidence in this Addreſs, and favourably accept the tender of this diminutive Tract, I ſhall eſteem that great Condeſcention, as an Eternal Obligation and Honour, conferr'd upon,

closer.signed: My good Lord, Your Lordſhips Moſt Devoted Humble Servant John Moore.

div.head: A PRACTICAL DISCOURSE, Shewing the Origine, Seat, Symptoms, Cauſe, &c.
div.p:
The Introduction in defence of the Author.IF ever any Perſon upon the Face of the Univerſe, that Dedicated his whole Life to the doing good, and rendring himſelf Beneficial to Mankind, has reaſon to complain of the Ill and Barbarous uſage he has encountred, from Men of his own Profeſſion, and others of a Superior Station, that pretend Authority to Licenſe or Suppreſs, all Practioners in the Noble and Uſeful Arts of Pharmacy, and Adminiſtring Phyſick, I am the Man; for ever ſince I took my leave of the Old and Uſeleſs way of giving Phyſick, as too many others do, Blindfold, by Traditional Preſcriptions, and made it my whole
Study and Buſineſs to keep up an entire Correſpondence and Agreement between Art and Nature, Theory and Practice; and made exact and particular Obſervations in the difference of Diſeaſes, the variety of Symptoms, caſual Accidents, and the diverſity of Conſtitutions in Humane Bodies; and have followed the dictates of a well-grounded Experience, in finding out the Eſſence of Diſeaſes, and the Efficacy of Proper Medicines to Cure them. The whole Tribe of common Practioners, and ſome graduated Profeſſors of Phyſick, that live lazing upon the little Knowledge that comes by Tradition, and by ſtuffing their Bills, and Patients with Nauſeous Repetitions, of unexperienc'd and conſequently ineffectual Medicines; have both unſufferably calumniated, traduced and ſlander'd me, with many ridiculous Stories and unjuſt Cenſures, as well as loaded me with ſuch hard and reproachful Names, as none but the bountiful beſtowers of them can deſerve; ſo that I am forc'd, to prevent others from being prejudiced by falſe Reports and malicious Inſinuations, to take this way of vindicating my Reputation, againſt the Inſults of Envious Men, who are as utter Strangers to my Perſon and Abilities, as themſelves are from the common Principles of Modeſty, Civility and good Manners.

I could with great facility recriminate upon my Enemies, but I never thought a Billings-Gate Dialect any Ornament, or an advantageous Character to a Sober Chriftian, which is ſeldom uſed, but by a buiſy ſort of Tatling Animals, who are out of Humour with every Body, becauſe their own ill nature will not ſuffer 'em to be
pleas'd with themſelves. Let Maevius and Bavius then admire one another, and rail at all the World beſides; I ſhall for the future be unconcern'd at thoſe who are as full of unjuſt Reproaches, as they are void of good Breeding. I wiſh to be hated by ſelf-intereſted Slanderers and their Abettors, for the ſame reaſon for which I deſire to be belov'd by all Ingenious, well meaning honeſt Men, under all Denominations; as for the reſt, I ſhall ſay with the Poet

l.hi: Ʋrg'd by the Baſe, I'm unconcern'd the while,
At leaſt regard it with a ſcornful Smile;
'Twere mean to think of Vengeance on the Vile.

div.p: However, ſince I know not how far their Hatred, inveterate and implacable Malice may extend to my prejudice, among thoſe that know not my veritable Character, I ſhall here employ a few Lines to anſwer all the Objections they have raiſed, and induſtriouſly ſcatter'd to blaſt my Reputation in the Practice of Phyſick, which I have followed with great Succeſs for many Years, and which the worſt of my Enemies cannot deny, without aſſurance enough to affirm, that the Sun is not riſen, when to their ſhame, it ſhines in their Faces from its Illuſtrious Meridian.

Objections againſt the Author.The firſt Quarter in which my profeſſed Enemies attack me, is, That I am but an Apothecary: 'Tis true, I lay claim to no greater Title, and yet cannot forbear ſaying, That that Objection is Ridiculous; ſince being an Apothecary, well versd in Pharmacy, in the Knowledge of Drugs, and the Compoſition of Medicines, is, the moſt certain
and regular ſtep towards the making of a good Phyſician: As has been proved by many Examples in London and other Places, where Men that ſervd their Times to Apothecaries, and kept Shop many Years, have afterwards took their Degree of Doctor in one of our own Univerſities, and practiſed with as great Applauſe, and it may be with more Succeſs, than the reſt of their only Graduated Brethren. Nor is this method unobſerved in other Learned Employments; for many Wiſe Men ſay, That the way to make an able Counſellor, is, Firſt to educate him as a Clerk to an Attorney. Having thus blown off this ignorant and contemptible Objection, I proceed to the Second; which is, That I never had, an Ʋniverſity Education, but am a mere Ignoramus, as they are pleas'd to Phraſe it; But how will they prove their latter Allegation? Did they ever Examine into my Learning and Ability? Do they know my Incapacity to perform what I undertake? If they did, without doubt I ſhould long ſince have heard of it in louder Terms, than by Private Whiſpers, Malicious Inſinuations and Secret Calumnies and Aſperſions; but ſuch is their Hatred, that what they dare not aver to my Face, or attempt to prove by Argument, they liberally ſupply by falſe Reports, and forged Clandeſtine Stories of my Inſufficiency, againſt a Thouſand credible Certificates and Reputable Teſtimonies to the contrary; and theſe I think ſufficient to ſtop the Mouths of Detraction and Envy, in the Opinion of all good People; and for others, that are miſlead by my Numerous Adverſaries into uncharitable Cenſures of me;
let them but conſider, that my Enemies treat me on the ſcore of Demetrius, for my ſafe and ſhort way of Practice, and a great number of Patients diminiſhing their Profit, they will not wonder that I am condemn'd in an Arbitrary Court, where Malice is the Proſecuter, Intereſt ſits as Judge, and ſordid Ignorance is Fore-Man of the Jury. I confeſs, I have not had the Advantage of an Academick Education, but am a ſincere lover of Learning, and deſirous of Knowledge, and tho' I cannot boaſt of poſſeſſing much, yet I can aſtute all Cenſorious Pedants, that by converſing with Learned Men, and a well choſen Library, I take as much pains to encreaſe my Knowledge, as ſome of them do by inſignificant Diverſions, and notorious Debaucheries, to loſe what they gain'd, if ever they gain'd any thing but Words at the Ʋniverſity. Beſides, this cavil is wholly Impertinent, ſince its well known, beyond a poſſibility of Contradiction, that I am Maſter of good Specificks, and eſtabliſh'd experimented Medicines, of my own Preparing, which Prescribing? Phyſicians cannot pretend to, tho' of the greateſt Conſequence to Mankind, and whoſe efficacious Vertues I am ſure of, and can rely upon, in the moſt difficult plunging Caſes in reſpect of Safety, and generally with Succeſs; and all this confirmed by numerous Teſtimonies of Cured Patients, which I am of Opinion, is all that ought t • be required of a good Phyſician; and yet for want of the empty Title of Doctor, and a Coach and Equipage, I muſt, it ſeems, be called Quack and Emperick, by choſe Doni of the Profeſſion, who have not much more Skill in
the true Practice of Phyſick, which I take to be the Cure of Diſeaſes, than what they collect from the old exploded Methodus Medendi, which when the World grows Wiſer, will vaniſh into its original nothing, and give place to ſolid, certain and veritable Experience in the Cure of Diſeaſes.

And that I may contribute to this great End, of advancing uſeful Knowledge in Phyſick, and that my Enemies may not think I am reduced to a perpetual ſilence in my own juſt Defence, by their vain Threatnings and injurious Miſrepreſentations of my Perſon and Capacity for the Practice of Phyſick, I have taken up a reſolution to Print ſeveral Diſcourſes upon thoſe Diſeaſes, that God has bleſs'd me with the Knowledge of, and given me wonderful ſucceſs in their Cures, that have frequently baffled the Endeavours of many Eminent Profeſſors: And ſhall begin with a Treatiſe upon the CHOLICK.

Now in diſcourſing this Subject, to avoid all unneceſſary and over Nice and Curious Diſtinction, and Definitions, that rather puzzle Men's Intellects, than benefit their Understandings, I ſhall under the general Name, vulgarly called Cholick, treat of it as an Accidental and Particular Diſtemper, ariſing from an evident Cauſe alone, and without a previous diſpoſition in any Perſon indifferently; for ſo, alterations in the Sex No • naturalia often raiſe great commotions in the Viſcera of the Belly with extremity of Pain: After that, I ſhall conſider this Diſeaſe in its Procartick or pre-exiſtent Cauſe, as co-operating with others that are ſubſequent, which will neceſſarily lead me to
particular Diſcourſes upon the various kinds, and the ſeveral Species of this Diſtemper under the denominations of the Cholick in the Stomach; the Hyſterick Cholick, the Scorbutick Cholick; the Iliack Paſſion, the Caeliack Cholick, a Diarrhea, a Lientary, a Dyſentry, &c. All which Diſtempers I ſhall treat particularly, and to avoid Confuſion and over burthening the Memory, under every Head I ſhall ſhew the Origine Seminium or Minera of each Diſeaſe; what part of the Body is primarily affected; then proceed to the Symptoms and Method of Cure, and conclude with ſome Obſervations and Examples, wherein my own Medicines have been wonderfully ſucceſsful; which I always keep ready prepared by me, to diſpoſe of, to all that think fit to come or ſend for them.

The Eſſence or Nature of the Cholick.The Cholick called in Greek
〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in Latin Collica Paſſio, becauſe by ſome Phyſitians, 'tis ſuppoſed, tho' falſly, to have its ſeat wholly in ſome part or other of the Second of the great Guts, called Colon; is a Vellication or ſevere Griping, Twitching, Gnawing Pain in certain Parts of the Abdomen, which commonly produce Vomitings, Cramps and Contractions, almoſt of all the Viſcera of the Belly: Sometimes the Navel and its Neighbouring Parts are drawn inward, accompanied with Pains as if they were boared with a Gimlet: Sometimes they ſwell, being blown up with the exceſs of Wind: The Inteſtines by an inverted Motion of the Fibres are often drawn upwards, inſomuch that the Belly being extreamly bound, diſcharges little or nothing at all; nay, tho' it be frequently provoked to do it by Glyſters and Suppoſitories, yet
it does not eaſily throw out its Contents.

That the Stomach is likewiſe convulſed with the Duodenum and Gall Bladder, manifeſtly appears from the plentiful vomiting of Yellow or Green Choler. Sometimes the Ʋreters and the Bladder which contains the Urine, are ſo contracted, that during the whole Fit, the Urine is either ſtopt, or voided more ſparingly: Beſides, the Head is grieved with Vertiginous effects, either preceding or following the invaſion of this Diſeaſe, and if the Cholick encreaſes and becomes Inveterate, it often cauſes Pain in the outward Members and terminates in a Palſey.

Its direful Effects.Nay, the Sick commonly endures all kinds of Pains; one while burning with intolerable Heat, another time chill'd with extream Cold; ſometimes it ſeems to be fix'd and as it were piercing the Loins, or • ther whiles pricking with wandring repeated Thruſts; anon diſtending or beating the Loins, or only preſſing them with the ſenſe of weight, or burning, corroding, rending Pain; or is troubled either with a continual or interrupted Pulſation, and afterward returning again, or wonderfully writhing and contorting any other way, ſcarce to be expreſſed by the Patient, or explain'd by the Phyſician.

Now tho' all the differences occurring in this Diſtemper with its Original are very difficult to be aſſign'd, numbred, or reduced into a certain Order, and much more to make an exact Examination of all the Symptoms and Cauſes, and thence to give a ſollid judgment of every one; yet I ſhall attempt it, by exhibiting them from the
beſt Authorities, and leave the choice to your own Election, as they are moſt agreeable to your Reaſon and Experience, which is the Miſtreſs both of the Learned and Unskilful.

The Origin of the Cholick.Some are of Opinion that the Origine of this Diſeaſe, proceeds from the efferveſcency of vicious Blood; others from an Obſtruction of the Capillary Veins of the Stomach and Guts, by which the Blood is forced to ſtand ſtill in the Veſſels, till at length after a great Diſtention the Veſſels burſt and the Blood is effuſſed, which breeds a ſenſible Inflamation and violent Pulſation about the Part affected. Others ſay it ariſes from an over viſcous Phlegm mix'd with Choler, offenſive both in its Saltiſh Acrimony and Volatile Oilineſs, by which the Viſcous Phlegm is rarified into Wind, and if the Excrements are contain'd beyond their due time, they harden and ſtick to the Gut, by which the natural Ferment is viciated, and the Windy Guſts are more rarified, and being ſhut up in the Cavity of the Gut Colon it cauſes a violent diſtenſion and contraction of it.

Some again impute it the diſorders and Convulſions of the Nerves running from the Meſenterick Plexus, which vicious humours as aforeſaid, lodg'd in the Inteſtines, and thoſe by a Forreign irritation of their Nerves, equally attended by the ſucceſſive returns of Cold, and Heat, cauſe tearing, wringing and c •••••• cting Pains.

Others aſcribe •• s Original to the abounding Acidity and Acrimony of the Pancreatick juice, occaſion'd by over ſharp Food; eating raw Fruits, by Summer Air too Hot, by Winter Air too Cold, or at leaſt
too Sharp; by Fear, Sorrow, extream Grief or Solicitude of Mind; by continued Watchings which conſume the Animal Spirits, and by conſequence encreaſing the Acrimony of any Humours, produce Hypocondriack ſuffocations, and alſo Pains, ſeverely racking and contorting the Guts. Now the Reaſons why I cannot agree with many Phyſicians, that Cholick Pains proceed from the ſharp and irritative contents of the Colon, is, becauſe thoſe Medicines which looſen the Belly, and copiousſly expel Featus's and the Faeces, would undoubtedly give moſt certain Relief, the contrary of which too often happens, viz. That after frequent or violent Purging, that Diſeaſe becomes worſe. Nor can I agree with the Notion, that Cholick Pains proceed only from the Pancreatick juice mix'd with Choler, becauſe it's impoſſible, according to Sylvius de la Boe that the Juice of the Pancreas in any manner or degree ſowre, ſhould mix with Choler, abounding with a bitter and volatile Salt. Therefore,

I firmly adhere to the Opinion of the Learned Dr. Willis, who with great reaſon, places the Origine of this Diſeaſe among the effects of the Brain and the Genus Nervoſum, alledging, that certain Recrements of the Nervous Humour, falling from the Brain by the Nerves, and paſſing thence into the Meſentry and other Foldings of the Abdomen, are there amaſs'd and heaped together, which if they are ſo groſs, thick and viſcous, that they cannot be received and ſent away by the Lymphaducts, or diſtill'd out into the Cavities of the Inteſtines, by the ſmall Branches of the Veſſels, then Stagnating and being heaped together by degrees into thoſe
Parts, they ariſe at length to an irritative plenitude: And afterward that Matter becoming more degenerate, and more offenſive by Stagnation, and growing turged on ſome occaſion; or of its own accord or elſe fermenting with the Salino-fix'd Humour, ſent thither from the Blood, will torture the Patient with very troubleſome and painful Corrugations in the Branches of the Nerves and Nervous Fibres, with which the Meſentery is innumerably furniſh'd: Which effects of them, do ſeldom or never ceaſe till the fermenting Matter is either diſcuſs'd, or expreſs'd into the Cavities of the Inteſtines, or at length by Care and the Application of proper Medicines, they are utterly ſubdued.

Having thus briefly ſhew'd you the Nature of the Cholick in the direful effects it produces, together with its Origination, I ſhall, according to promiſe, proceed to the Place that is primarily affected in Human Bodies.

The ſeat of the Cholick Senertus and Riverius, place it in the upper Orifice of the Stomach, which is of exquiſite Senſe, by reaſon of the intermixture of Nerves, with which it is ſtored from the vaga ſexta, from whence Branches being communicated to the Heart that noble Part is alſo affected by Conſent, and diſperſes the Pain into almoſt every part Internal and external.

Dr. Blankard, Profeſſor of Phyſick, at Middleburgh, in Zealand, ſays, The Cholick is a vehement Pain, proceeding from an ill diſpoſition of the Animal Spirits, ſeated in the Abdomen, but begins in the Nervous Plexus's or Foldings of the Meſentery, and is
by ſome Men falſly imputed to have its reſidence in the Gut Colon.

Michael Etmuller, late Profeſſor of Phyſick in the Univerſity of Leiptſick, ſays, Cholick Pains and Gripings in the great Guts, are chiefly felt in the Colon, eſpecially in that part of it towards the circumference of the Belly, upon the Left-ſide, where 'tis ſtraitned and incurvated, and conſequently more liable to the blaſt and ſhocks of Wind, and more apt to ſtop the Circulation of the Excrements, and cauſe their Swelling up into a hard or ſoft Tumor. This Pain and Tumor is frequently imputed to the Spleen, but erroneouſly; for the Colon, ſays he, is its uſual and proper Seat; and ſometimes it veers about to the Right-ſide of the Belly, upon the outermoſt Circumference, where the ſame Colon purſues its Courſe.

Sometimes theſe Pains reach only the Small Guts, and then their Station is about the Navel and Centre of the Belly, and are much more violent than thoſe in the Great Guts; if they range not beyond the Duodenum, or the beginning of the Jejunum, they are felt in the Loins, and are often miſtaken for Nephritick Pains, or thoſe cauſed by the Convulſion of the Meſenterick Nerves, or Tumors, or Ulcers in the Pancreas. I dare not ſay any of theſe Opinions are Heterodox, becauſe ſometime or other Pains do poſſeſs all the Parts above mention'd.

However, for very good Reaſons grounded upon many Experiments in Anatomy, I adhere chiefly to Doctor Willis, who ſays, The Part in Human Bodies primarily affected in the Cholick, is the Meſentery, and its Nervous Foldings under the Navel, which cauſes
cruel Pain, as if a Stake was ſtuck there, or a Piercer were making a Hole: Beſides, round about, almoſt in the whole Abdomen, by reaſon of the Inteſtines being variouſly drawn forward and backward, at the ſame time in different Places, wandring Pains ſhoot this way and that way; and the motion of the Fibres being diſcompoſed or inverted, as well in thoſe Parts as in the primary Veſſels, the Belly is in a manner always bound, and there follows ſometimes a ſupperſſion of Urine, or very little is made. Beſides, the Duodenum the Gall Bladder with its Channels and the bottom of the Stomach being affected with a Cramp, and their Fibres being drawn upward, a frequent Vomiting with a copious caſting up Matter of Yellow or Greeniſh colour often happens during the Fit.

In a Fit of the Cholick, alſo beſides Pains of the Belly, there are likewiſe violent Pains of the Loins, raging in the 1ower parts of the Back, which certainly cannot proceed from the irritation of any Inteſtine; but its eaſy to conceive they may ariſe from a Morbific Cauſe lodg'd in the Meſentery: For inaſmuch as ſeveral conſiderable Nerves of the Loins enter into the great Nervous folding of the Meſentery; ſo from hence, not only painful Convulſions are conveyed by conſent from one Part to another; but its alſo probable, that certain Recrements of the Back likewiſe, and of the Loins, are derived into the Meſentery by this Paſſage, and that in ſome ſort, for this reaſon, Scorbutical Perſons are ſo very obnoxious to Gripes of the Belly, and Looſeneſs that attends it, which confirms me in the Opinion that the Nervous Flexus
of the Meſentery, is the firſt Part affected with the Cholick, and that its ſeat is not in the Cavities or T • nicles of the Inteſtines, nor the Morbifick Matter conveyed by the Arteries, but by Nerves.

Diagnoſtick Symptoms. Diagnoſtick Signs of the Cholick, are, very ſharp Pains, ſometimes moveable and other whiles fix'd to a certain place; ſometimes the Pain is in the region of the Stomach or in the Reins, ſometimes above and ſometimes below the Navel, ſo that by the compariſon of other Signs, you muſt diſtinguiſh between the Cholick and Pains of the Stone or Spleen, which are frequently miſtaken one for the other, even by Phyſicians themſelves.

Prognoſtick Symptoms of the Cholick. Prognoſticks of the Cholick, are vulgarly enough known, that is to ſay, an Accidental Cholick riſing from an evident cauſe alone, is commonly ſafe, and admits of an eaſy Cure; but an habitual one, is not eradicated but with great Difficulty, as to its diſpoſition, ſo that the Fits may return no more; for ſometimes the Fits themſelves, notwithſtanding the Application of Medicines, are very obſtinate and continue many Days, nay, Weeks and Months, and ſometimes are never cured but by Death. Thus much for ſigns; But ſince I have branch'd out this Diſeaſe into ſeveral Parts, I ſhall take leave, once for all, to ſhew, how you may diſtinguiſh one Diſeaſe from another by the Urine.

Signs by the Urine.If the Urine is Watery, 'tis a Nephritick Cholick, if highly tinctur'd towards the middle, and colour'd on the Surface, and the Anus is obſtinately bound; 'tis a Scorbutick Cholick; if Reſpiration is difficult and
the Breaſt afflicted, 'tis a Hyſterick Cholick; if the Convulſion of the Inteſtines is accompanied with Pain extending to the Pubes and Haunch-Bone, the Womb is diſorder'd; if the Urine is clear and of a reddiſh Yellow, 'tis a Cholerick Cholick, if the Pain is tearing and the Urine Milky and Pale, impregnated with a large Sediment, the Meſenterick Nerves are affected.

Cauſes of the common Cholick.The Antecedent Cauſes of the Common Cholick, which I only treat of under this Head, are, the Diſorder and Convulſions of the Nerves running from the great Meſenterick Plexus, which cauſe tearing, wringing and contracting Pains: Sometimes occaſion'd by Nephritick Pains and Child-Birth, when the Meſenterick folding, being irritated, by its concourſe with the Nerves of the Kidneys and the Womb, Antecedent Cau-Cauſes. pulls and contracts both the Stomach and Guts which it ſupplies with Nerves. At other times they are retainers to ſome fix'd, permanent, habitual Cauſe, which tho' it lye hid for ſome time, has always an Aſcendant in the Body. Theſe are either Hypochondriack, Hyſterick or Scorbutick, as I ſhall further ſhew, when I treat particularly of thoſe Diſeaſes a part, and are owing to the Convulſion of the Meſenterick Plexus, to which the Inteſtines are annex'd, being gall'd with a peccant Acid.

Procatartick Cauſes.The Procatartick, or Pre-exiſtent Cauſe of this Diſeaſe which co-operates with others that are ſubſequent, are two fold; Firſt, That many Recrements or ſuperfluous things are heaped together in the Nervous Liquor; and Secondly, That they being admitted chiefly into the Nerves of the Viſcera of the Belly, and ſo conveyed into the Meſentery,
there create the Morbid Minera's of this Diſtemper; for the former of theſe generally happening by the Diſtemper of the Brain, by admitting Heterogeneous Particles with the Nervous Juice into its cuſtody, the whole Animal Oeconomy is ſo diſturb'd, that it cannot evacuate the common ſuperfluities by its ordinary Conveyance; and this cauſes the incongruous Matter that cannot be ſent from the Brain, to force its paſſage into the Nerves of the Par vagum, which are open and ready to receive it. Secondly, That this ſuperfluous Matter running in this manner into the Par vagum of the Nerves, is depoſed in the Meſentery, or other foldings within the Abdomen, and neceſſarily makes the Morbid ſeat in the Meſentery.

Evident Cauſes.The evident Cauſes of the Cholick are alſo of two ſorts; Firſt, Such as being injurious to the Brain and Genus Nervoſum, cauſe the Morbifick Matter to ſuper abound: Or, Secondly by agitating the Blood and Humors, ſtir up the conglobated Maſs to Pain, cauſing more fervent and ſudden efferveſcencies. And here ſome will imagine I ſhould proceed to diſcourſe the many and diverſified occaſions, by which the Pains of the Cholick are caus'd in Perſons pre-diſpoſed to them; but that would be nauſeating the Reader with Cramben biſcoctum, having ſufficiently done it already, in the Paragraph ent • tuled the direful effects of the Cholick, Page the 14th.

Cure of the Ch • lick.And now according to the Method I have preſcribed to my ſelf, I am brought to treat of what ought to be the Main and Principal deſign of every Practitioner in Phyſick in
all Diſeaſes, viz. The Cure of the Diſeaſe. To compaſs which great end, Three primary Indications are ſuggeſted. Firſt, To appeaſe the Pains in the Fit. Secondly, To take away the Cauſe of the Diſeaſe that the Fits may no more, or not ſo frequently return. Thirdly, To re-invigorate the Patient's Strength, and fortify his Conſtitution, in order to the Comfortable enjoyment of Life.

To appeaſe the torturing Pains in the Paroxiſm, Lenifying and Emollient Glyſters only, ought to be frequently injected into the Body, that the Corrugations of the Fibres may be mitigated, and the raging of the Spirits appeaſed. To this end, Warm Milk with Sugar, or rather Moloſſus, or Syrup of Violets: Alſo Emollient Decoctions of March-Mallows, Herb Mercury, and the Flowers of Melilot with Oil of Almonds; alſo a ſtrong Decoction of a Sheep's-Head with the Wool on it, or Calves-Feet, are proper to be uſed: Sometimes a Glyſter of mear Oil of Olives or of Linſeeds, have given Eaſe, when others have failed. But if this ſort of Glyſters are ineffectual and do not come away, or anſwer their end ſtronger muſt be uſed, to force the Humours from the little Mouths of the Arteries. For this purpoſe • et Carminative or bitter Decoctions be prep • red, in which diſſolve Electuary Diaphoenic •• , Diacatholicon, or e Baccis Lauri, or Species Hierae, to which Liquors its cuſtomary to add, Two or Three Ounces of the infuſion of Crocus Mettalorum: Or to a Pound of an Emollient Decoction, add of Venice Turpentine diſſolv'd with the Yolk of an Egg, one Ounce; or take the Ʋrine of a Healthy Man, Venice Turpentine diſſolv'd, one Ounce and half, and
with one Ounce of Moloſſus mix'd with the reſt, make a Glyſter. The Balſamick Particles of the Turpentine diffuſed every where, are deſign'd to remove the Morbifick or Stagnating Matter, or encline that which is Acetous, or otherwiſe degenerate, to a better Temperament.

If the Inteſtines are much contracted by vicious Matter lodg'd within them, Purgations ought to be prohibited, for fear they promo • e the Contraction, and lock up the Excrements cloſer. If this Caſe happens in your Practice, Whey, or an Ounce of the Oil of Almonds, with Canary Wind and Sperma Caeti, are more effectual than the ſtrongeſt Catharticks, If the Cholick is attended with a Tenacious viſcid Humour, and a heavy boring Pain, Purgatives mix'd with attenuating Specificks are allowable; tho' I have obſerv'd, 'tis better to do ſo after the Fit has made ſome progreſs, and the Symptoms are a little mittigated, than juſt in the beginning, eſpecially if the Pain is violent; but take notice, that if the Guts are inflamed, all Laxatives of whatſoever • ind are extreamly pernicious; for a fierc •
• nd very violent Cholick, if it proceed from an Inflamation or Abſceſs of ſome of the Inteſtines, generally uſhers in a Mortal Iliack Paſſion.

External Applications.As for External Applications againſt Cholicks, let the Belly and Navel be well fomented with Liniments, of expreſs'd Oils, mix'd with thoſe that are Diſtill'd. Galbanum melted and mix'd with the Diſtill'd Oils of Spike and Amber. Plaifters made of Tachamahas, Balſam of Peru, or that of Bay-Berries, with that of Tobacco; Cataplaſms of Horſe-Dung, with Oil of Rue; and quilted Bags of Millet-ſeeds,
or of Anodyn and Aromatic Ingretlients; are like wiſe apply'd to the Belly with good ſucceſs. But if the Gripes of the Belly do not remit by the uſe of theſe things, you muſt have recourſe to Hypnoticks, which being given in a ſitting Doſe, often gives Relief. And in continued Cholicks notwithſtanding ſome Men, Whoſe Ignorance, is as conſiderable as their Inſolence, loudly clamour againſt the uſe of Mercurial Medicines, yet the raiſing a gentle Salivation when the Morbifick Matter is plentifully gather'd together in the Nervous Plexus's, and other places about the Abdomen, and there ſticking faſt, ſo as not to be moved by other Medicines, Calomel may be given to the Relief of the Patient, and without Reproach to the Phyſician.

The Preſervative Indication.To refreſh the Strength and falling Spirits of the Sick, and to order yet a greater Apparatus againſt the Diſeaſe, give Liquid Laudanum tartariz'd, at Bed-time, in a Spoonful of the Water of Camomil Flowers, drinking after it, of the ſame ſix Spoonfuls, and let it be repeated every other, or every third Night. And whilſt you are uſing theſe Medicines for appeaſing Pains, let Purging Remedies have their due Turns, to deſtroy the Seminium of the Diſeaſe, and to prevent its return, Vomiting and Purging, and in a Hot Temperament Ph • ebotomy ought to be uſed: And inſtead of Baths and Sudorificks, Diure
• icks may be more advantageouſly given.
And where the Cholick is of long continuance and obſtinate, Spaw-Water coming from Iron-Mines, are often uſed with good Succeſs:

The Vital Indication.Next, The Vital Indication ought to be join'd with the Curatory, and to be now and then interchangeably uſed with it: To that end, let Remedies be uſed which ſupport the Patient's Strength, refreſh his
• pirits and procure certain times of Truce againſt the Fits of the Diſeaſe. Let the Diſeaſed be duſy ſupplied with Cordials, Paregoricks and Hypnoticks, which in the Cholick are ſo abſolutely neceſſary, that the Patient cannot live without them, nor the Phyſician juſtif himſelf, before the Tribunal of his own Conſcience. In Conſtitutions that are not Hot, Spirits of Heart-Horn, of Soot, of Sal-Armoniack ſuccinated, alſo Tincture of Antimony, or o • Coral, are all very commendable. And when the Sick is deliver'd from his Pains, and has recover'd a competency of Strength; to compleat his Cure, I recommend travelling long Journies on Horſeback, or in a Coach, for ſuch excitations of the Parts, will ſtrengthen the Bowels, ſhake off the Relicks of the Diſeaſe, and make Life Pleaſant and Comfortable, till the devouring Teeth of Time ſhall deſtroy that as well as every thing elſe.

The Author's own Remedies.Having thus briefly given you the Nature, Origine, Seat, Symptoms, Cauſe and Cure of this Excruſiating Diſeaſe call'd the Cholick, with the choiceſt Remedies uſed by the moſt celebrated Phyſicians of former Ages, and the preſent Time; I ſhall now, according to Promiſe, ſay ſomething of my own Medicines, that the bountiful Giver of all good things has bleſs d me with the Knowledge of, and which I can depend upon, from uncontradicted Experience in many Years Practice, for the certain Cure of this Diſeaſe, in all Cureable Caſes, and for giving Eaſe in the moſt
Dangerous, whoſe Obſtinacy and Inveteracy will not admit, of a Perfect Cure: Which Remedies are of three, ſorts, a Chimical Elixir, an Anticholical Cordial Water, Pills, and an Electuary; all ſafe and Salubrious in their Nature, and effectual in their Operations, as will be atteſted by numerous Patients that have committed themſelves to my Care, and found extraordinary Benefit by them; when Men of greater Names, after long Tryals have been unſucceſsful, to the infinite Trouble and great Expence of the Diſeaſed; both which will be prevented by the Method I take, in a happy conjunction of Speculative and Experimental Knowledge, as the only remedy of the Inconveniencies that cramp a Succeſsful Practice.

The Medicines I exhibit are ſure, and the Knowledge I have of their vertue, is not the effect of my Reaſoning; but of my Obſervation, ſo that thoſe that uſe them will find them Succeſsful. I ſay, this Knowledge is not the Fruits of my Reaſon, becauſe in reality it is not; and further, to ſet this Aſſertion right, it cannot be ſo; for in the matter of Medicines, we have no other way to follow, but that of Obſervation: For to offer to diſcover, by Reaſon alone, the vertue of Medicaments, is the way never to find what we ſeek for I theref re apply my ſelf to Experience, and leave thoſe Tricks and vain Subtilities, which according to Quintilian, render us like thoſe little Inſects, that are never pleas'd but when they are among Thorns and Briars. Its high time to ſhake off this School Phyſick, which is good for nothing but wrangling, and attain a poſitive Phyſick, which is of uſe in Practice. By poſitive
Phyſick, I don't mean one made up of Authorities, which conſiſts in knowing the Sentiments of divers Authors upon a controverted Point, as in Poſitive Divinity: But I mean one that conſiſts of poſitive Matters of Fact, which teaches what has been often ſucceſsful in the ſame Circumſtances; and I may be bold to ſay, that Poſitive Phyſick, regulated by Method, is the true Phyſick.

School Phyſick, enables Practitioners to make ſmart Repartees, to come off handſomely in a controverted Point; and the other makes us ſenſible and Prudent, ſo as to order nothing but what's convenient: The out makes us Headſtrong and Opinionative, and the other makes us honeſt Phyſicians, who ſeek for nothing but how to inform our ſelves, and to be uſeful: The one ſeeks for Evaſ • ons how to defend himſelf under a Diſappointment, and the other for Medicines to Cure Diſtempers: The one conſults his Ideas, and the other conſults his Reaſon and Experience: The one makes Pedants, and the other Phyſicians.

A Chymical Elixir, and its Operation.And firſt, my Chymical Elixir, is in its own Nature peculiarly adapted to the Cure of the Cholick, becauſe its innate vertues are powerful in allaying Pains, taking away the Cauſe of the Diſeaſe, and re-invigorating the Patient's Strength, and refreſhing his Spirits, by which means, and not by any Narcotick quality in the Medicine, Nature is enabled to expel the Morbifick Matter lodg d in the Nervous Plexus's of the Meſentery, and to ſubdue and conquer the Diſeaſe. This Elixir alſo is endued with an excellent Quality, to Purify the Blood and Nervous
Liquors, and keep them in a due and regular Craſis, in order to prevent the engendring of Morbifick Matter; Strengthens the Brain and the Nervous Foldings of the Abdomen, and removes the preſent Procatarxis of the Cholick, and hinders the Invaſions of Pains for the Future, ſo that they ſhall ſeldom or never return afterwards.

How to be taken, and its happy Effects.Which Elixir is to be taken, Ten Drops at a time, when aſſaulted by Cholick Pains, in Five or Six Spoonfuls of Generous Wine, ſmooth clear Ale, or well brew d Table-Beer, every half Hour till the Pain is abated, and then forbear taking any more Drops for that time, unleſs the Pain returns. This Quantity of Drops is proper for Men; but the Fair Sex muſt take but Five or Six Drops at a time, in Two or Three Spoonfuls of either of the above mention'd Liquors, obſerving the ſame Rules as are given to Men. But if the Sick are enclined to Vomit up whatever they take, let the Patient take the ſame quantity of Drops in a ſma •• er quantity of Liquor. Some Perſons of both Sexes can take a greater number of Drops than others; and in violent Fits of the Cholick, if the Patient has not eaſe with a ſmall number of Drops, let them add two Drops every time they take them, till eaſy, then take no more that time. As to the quantity of the Drops the Patient is the proper judge, who finding what number of Drops beſt agrees with his Conſtitu • ion, his own Reaſon will induce him in all Effects, to ſtick to that Quantity.

When either Man or Woman takes my Elixir in the Day time, let them lye down upo • a Bed, diſpoſe themſelves to Reſt, and
if they find their Stomachs any way diſorder'd, the longer they repoſe, the ſooner they will find Refreſhment and Eaſe.

If the Sick enter into a courſe of taking my Elixir, to eradicate this Diſtemper and put a final end to his tormenting Pains, let him take Four Drops at Night when he is going to Bed, in a Glaſs of ſome, of the Vehicle afore named, or in Bohe Tea, and continue ſo to do, by adding One Drop every ſucceſſive Night, till he has imbibed 20, 30, or 40 Drops; or at leaſt the certain number that agrees with him, and adhere to that, till he finds himſelf recover'd; always lying long in Bed in the Morning, that the Elixir may the ſooner produce its deſired happy Effect.

An Advertiſement to Water-Drinkers.Further, if the Sick has at any time, found ſome Benefit by drinking Spaw-Water, and is deſirous to continue it, becauſe his Bowels are too Hot, let him put Six Drops of my Elixir into half a Pint of Spaw-Water, and drink it going to Bed, for a Month together; for, this Elixir is the beſt Medicine in the World, to make all Mineral Waters paſs off well and quickly by Urine or Seige; which if they ſtay long in the Body, by taking up their Quarters in the Head or Feet, they will cauſe the Vertigo, or Gout, as is often found by dreadful Experience. Which may ſerve as a cautionary. Advertiſement, to all that accuſtom themſelves for Diverſion or Neceſſity ſake, to drink Tunbridge, Epſom, Dullege, Kenſington, Iſlington, North-Hall, Bath, Northampton-ſhire, Derby-ſhire, or York-ſhire-Waters, that they always carry a ſmall Bottle of my Elixir along with them, for prevention of ſuch ill Accidents as frequently come
to paſs, by drinking thoſe Waters alone, and to effect more ſafely, certainly and ſpeedily their Intentions in drinking thoſe Mineral Waters, which for want of uſing my Elixir with them, generally prove ineffectual.

This Elixir, a name taken from the Arabick Word Eleeſchir, ſignifying Powerful, is alſo effectual againſt the Stone, Gravel, and Bloody Urine; ſtops Vomiting and a Looſneſs, and is a proper Medicine againſt Chatars, Coughs, and all Diſeaſes incident to the Head and Breaſt. It continues its whole Vertue in all Climates, and conſequently is fit to be carried, as it has been, to the Eaſt or Weſt-Indies, to any of the Northern Countries, the Mediteranean, or the South-Seas. It will laſt more than Twenty Years, and no Family that has Experienc'd its Vertues in many others, as well as this Diſtemper, will be without it.

The Author's Cordia • Cholick Waters.And ſince in this Diſeaſe, all things, tho' properly enough contrived and invented, do not agree with all Perſons, nor pleaſe in in the ſame Form of Compoſition, and that ſome Palates diſreliſh what others imbibe with Pleaſure, ſo there is ſometimes a Neceſſity of changing and altering Medicines in reſpect of their Form, as well as Ingredients in their Compoſition, that they may more effectually operate upon the different vicious Humours, and on the various Parts affected.

To anſwer all theſe Ends, I invented my Cordial Anticholical Water, whoſe vertues far exceed the common Tincture of Steel and of Antimony and Amber, ſo much extoll'd in the Cure of the Cholick; becauſe after a peculiar manner, it gives Eaſe by expelling
the viſcous Recrements in the great Meſenterick Plexus, to which the Inteſtines are annexed, and allays the griping Pains that follow the irregular Cure of Fevers, which are caus'd, by transferring the Morbifick Matter to the Glandules of the Meſentery, and the ſubſequent irritation of its Nerves. This Anticholical Water, or Solar Liquor, has alſo both a Diuretick and Carminative Quality, and has admirable effects, both in Tender and Robuſt Conſtitutions, and I often give it with great Succeſs, either it ſelf, or mix'd with other proper Specificks, as a Spur in Hot Diſcraſies of the Viſcera with a predominancy of aduſt Sulphur, as alſo in Flitting, Scorbutical, and irregular Boilings of the Blood and Nervous juice, which ſeldom or never fails of doing good in the moſt deſperate Caſes I have met with, in many Years Practice.

How to be taken.This Water is to be taken by Two or Three Spoonfuls at any time, when the Sick is grieved with the Cholick; either by it ſelf, or put into a Glaſs of warm Ale, or burnt White-Wine, and being repeated as occaſion requires, the Phyſician will accompliſh his main end, and the Patient if he is a Perſon of common Ingenuity, Gratitud • and Honeſty, will not grudge his Expenc • of Time or Money, in purchaſing ſo efficacious Remedy.

The Third Noſtrum I employ for the Cure of the Cholick, I call Pillulae Anticolicae, or Anticholical Pills; They are compounded of the choiceſt Ingredients in the whole Materia Medica, and require a long time and great Care and Pains in their Preparation, the Maſs being an Extract and no common
Compoſition, as will appear in their Operation, and the happy effects produced by them. Now you having read in the foregoing Diſcourſe, that in ſome Caſes, and eſpecially when the Inteſtines are much contracted by Viſcous Matter contain'd in them, that Purging Medicines are not to be uſed; and that all other Caſes, for the Cure of the Cholick, ſtrong Catharticks are abſolutely neceſſary; to avoid theſe extreams, I have choſen the Golden mean, and ſo contrived my Anticholical Pills, by mixing attenuating and mol
• ifying Ingredients with Purgatives, that they will Work but gently, tho' very effectually, in order to diſcuſs or expel the Peccant Humours by degrees, without offering Violence to Nature, by being over haſty in th • Cure, and to that end adminiſtring over powerful Purgatives, which rather weaken the Patient, than mitigate his Pains, or diminiſh his Diſtemper. But my Pills are Hermetically compounded, and at the ſame time both throw out the ſharp offen • ing Humours, corroborate the Stomach, fortify the Spirits, and ſtrengthen the whole Body againſt the future Invaſion of the Diſeaſe, as the only ſafe and eaſy way to a perfect Cure, which theſe Pills, taken according to the following Directions, very ſeldom ••• ve behind them.

Directions for taking the Pills.They are to be taken, one pill late at Night, at the time of going to Reſt, every third or fourth Night, and if that Pill does not Work pretty early in the Morning, take one or two Pills more every two Hours till they Operate gently, but if it makes the Patient Sick in his Stomach, and doth not Purge him, let him Diſſolve an
Ounce of Epſom Salt, or ſix Drams of the Lenitive Electuary, in a Pint of Water Gruel, or Mutton-Broath, and drink it Blood-warm, the Pills will have the ſame effect, if they are forced to be purg'd off; Two, Three, or Four Stools is ſufficient for one time: Keep very warm, and drink nothing cold that Day. After taking them, let the Sick drink large draughts of thin Chicken Broath, Mutton Broath, or Water Gruel, or for want of them Poſſet Drink, to dilute the ſharp Humours, caſt them out, or their Acrimony being taken off, reduce them to a better Temper: Which you will ſoon find, if this Courſe is duly repeated, as often as there is occaſion, and when there is none, take no more Pills, for I don't give them for Lucre of Money, but to anſwer the Intention of Healing, for therein conſiſts my Intereſt. Theſe Pills are good for the Scurvy, Pains in any part of the Body, King's Evil, corrupt Humours in any Part of the Body, the Itch, Leprofie, Old Ulcers, Worms, Gravel, Stones and in other Caſes where Purging is neceſſary.

The Fourth Remedy.Thoſe Days wherein the Patient does not Purge, I give a Cordial Electuary, which I call Electuarium Anticolica, or my Anticholical Electuary, which is the Fourth Remedy for the Cure of this Diſeaſe, and which ſeldom fails, if the Diſeaſe is Cureable, this Electuary being indued with ſuch rare, uncommon and well experienc • d Vertues, agreeable to the Dictates of Nature and Art, and ſo ſignificantly adapted to the Cure of the Cholick, in all its various kinds, where purging is neceſſary or unneceſſary and dangerous, that the Patient will ſeldom be perfectly cured without
it; becauſe as I have found by repeated Experience, that when all other Remedies preſcribed by the beſt Hands have been ineffectual, this Electuary has done the Work, by corroborating the Stomach, correcting its vicious Fermentation, retrieving its depraved Appetite, and reſtoring its almoſt loſt Tone to a regular and ſanative Craſis.

Directions for taking this Electuary.This Electuary is ſometimes alſo to be taken in the Morning on an empty Stomach: Its Doſe is about the quantity of a Nutmeg, faſting an Hour after it, and again at Four or Five in the Afternoon, for 10, 15, 20, or 30 Days, when you uſe no Purgatives. Eat what Dyet is moſt nouriſhing and ſits light upon the Stomach, and abſtain from nothing ſo much as Milk and Stale Beer. And now I might be Very Copious, in the Commendation and Praiſe of theſe Four Remedies, invented by, and I believe only known to my ſelf, and are diſpoſed of at no Place, but my Dwelling-Houſe; but that Perſons who know me not, may not think I harangue to promote my own Profit in ſelling them, I ſhall wave it for the preſent, and leave every Man that buys and uſes them, to give them what Character they Deſerve. For when I have ſaid all I can, Wiſe Men will not regard what is ſaid of them, but what Cures have been, and may be accompliſh'd by them. And from hence I proceed to Obſervations, and Examples of Perſons cured of the Cholick, by the regular uſe of my afore named Remedies of which its needleſs to give you great Numbers, tho' I am plentifully furniſh'd with them; becauſe the Publick bas almoſt Weekly notice of Perſons cured by me in
Certificates under the Hands of my Patien • s, well atteſted, and Printed in the Publick News Papers.

Examples of Perſons Cured.A Gentlewoman of good Reputation, extreamly afflicted with the Cholick for many Years, after ſhe had taken, as ſhe thought, the beſt Advice that could be given in London, was recommended to my Care for the Cure of her Cholick. I gave her Antimonial Emeticks, Chalybeats, Catharticks and Alcalious Medicines, but without any effect, ſhe continuing ſtill in a ſad and deplorable Condition. While ſhe was empty, ſhe had an abatement of her Pain; but ſhe no ſooner Eat, but her Pains return'd and continued till her Food was Digeſted. At the ſame time when ſhe labour'd under this Diſeaſe, ſhe was often overwhelm'd with Vapours; often complain'd of Pain between her Shoulders and in other Parts, and well ſhe might; for conſidering the Scituation of the Parts, I found that when ſhe was full, her Stomach preſſed upon the Pancreas, which is a ſort of a Pillow to keep the Stomach from rubbing againſt the Vertebre's of the Back, and ſoon after diſcover'd, that the Pancreas and Pilorus were the Parts affected, occaſion'd by the Acidity of the Pancreas and the Unctiouſneſs of the Gall, which had produced an Ʋlcer in the Pancreas, which with the Pylorus was full of Matter, and when I had interchangeably given her my forenamed Arcana's, ſhe threw out at times upward and downward, a prodigious quantity of Pus, and then adminiſtring proper Pacificks and Healers, ſhe was perfectly cured, retired into the Country, where ſhe continues in Health to this Day.

This Gentlewoman being unwilling to have her Name publiſh'd, I will not diſobtige her in doing it; and ſhall take this opportunity to ſatisfie the Publick, that I never Print any Perſon's Name without their leave, or a Teſtimony under the Patient's Hand; but if any Perſon ſeems to doubt the truth of it, his curioſity may be ſatisfied by her Brother, a Merchant, who was an Eye-Witneſs of the Cure, and dwells at Humberton, in the Pariſh of Hackney, in Middleſex.

Grace, Wife of Thomas Hogges Weaver, dwelling in Church-ſtreet, in Coverlet-ſtreet, next Houſe to the Sign of the Lyons, was troubled with the Cholick ſix whole Years together, in which time ſhe had the Advice of ſeveral Phyſitians, but they doing her no good, at laſt ſhe apply'd her ſelf to me, and I cured her out of mere Charity, who has ſince been ſo grateful, as to recommend ſeveral other Patients to me, who were in better Circumſtances in regard of Wealth, who all as well as her ſelf have • een perfectly Cured by the uſe of my aforenamed Medicines.

A Tradeſman in the City of London, who had ſuffer'd intolerable Cholical Pains, and had taken ſeveral Medicines from his own Phyſitian and Apothecary for a conſiderable time, was induced to apply himſelf to me, and I gave him Eaſe immediately, and in a very ſhort time after, perfectly cured him. Thoſe that doubt the truth of this matter, if they think ſit to enquire of me, I ſhall direct them to the Perſon himſelf that was
Cured, who will readily atteſt the Truth of what I have here aſſerted, to the Satisfaction of any Perſon, that is not obliged by Intereſt to ſhew himſelf Incredulous.

The Cholick in the Stomach.Having now finiſh'd what I had to ſay of an Accidental Cholick, according to the Method propoſed, I am obliged to treat of the Cholick as complicated or joined with other Diſeaſes, and that which leads the Van, is the Stomachical Chotick, and that very juſtly, becauſe the Minera of all Chronical Diſeaſes are to be ſought in the Stomach: And if the upper Orifice of it, which is of exquiſite Senſe, by reaſon of the intermixture of Nerves, with which it is plentifully furniſh'd from the vaga ſexta, Branches whereof being communicated to the Heart, that noble part being affected, then the Diſeaſe is called in Greek 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 vel 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and in Latin Cardiacus dolor, the Pain of the Heart; but if the lower Orifice called Pylorus be affected, it is called Dolor, ſeu Colica Ventriculi, Pain, or the Cholick in the Stomach, more eſpecially if it proceed from Wind.

Cauſes of the Cholick in the Stomach.The Internal Cauſes of this Diſeaſe, ſometimes proceed from great Oppletion and Pain of the Stomach, ſometimes from frequent and violent Vomiting, which ariſes from the Chyle there degenerated into a Maſs of Corruption; but oftner from the Morbifick Matter brought thither, either by the conveyance of the Blood, or alſo of the Nervous Juice, and either depoſed within the Cavity of the Stomach, or fix'd in the Plexus's of the Nerves, and in the Membranes appertaining to it. Sometimes Worms gnawing the Tunicles of the Stomach cauſe this Diſeaſe, or Wind
lodg'd in the Cavity of the Stomach, which cauſes Swellings and painful Diſtenſion, or from ſharp Phlegm or Green and Black Choler; whoſe ſharp Vapours cauſe Pain, or from corrupt Matter from an Impoſthume in the Liver, or the Breaſt, Diſeaſes of the Stomach, and Parts adjoining; ill Humours from the whole Body as in Fevers, Choler from the Liver, Melancholly from the Spleen, Salt Phlegm from the Head; all theſe may be the Cauſes of the Cholick in the Stomach.

The External Cauſes of this Malady, may be corrupt Nouriſhment, Viands too Hot that breed Wind or Choler: Meat taken in too large quantity, Poyſon, or ſtrong ſharp and dangerous Medicines uncorrected.

Symptoms of the Cholick in the Stomach. Diagnoſtick Signs, are, Pain in the Enſiformis, or lower part of the Breaſt-Bone, which ſignifie that the upper Orifice of the Stomach is affected with very ſharp Pain, that will not ſuffer the Patient to take any Reſt, and ſometimes cauſe an inveterate Headach, the Megrim, Vertigo and the Epilepſy. In the other Parts of the Stomach the Symptoms are not ſo violent, but are truly Cholical, and exactly reſemble that Diſeaſe in its utmoſt Latitude.

Prognoſtick Symptoms are ominous, for this Diſeaſe is more danger • us than any other Diſeaſe of the Stomach, and the Danger is greater if it is accompanied with a Fever, for in ſuch a caſe, according to Hippocrates, Death is at hand. Its leaſt dangerous if it proceeds from Worms; tho' even in that, ſometimes dangerous Symptoms appear and the Patient dies. In ſhort, the Prognoſticks are uſually the Symptoms of Hypocondriack Illneſs; and if they happen upon the recovery of a Diſeaſe,
portends its relapſe; if they come from Wind that cannot be removed a Dry Dropſie follows. If they ſtink horribly, they are very Malignant and Contagious.

Cure of a Cholick in the Stomach.The method of Curing a Stomachical Cholick, if it be not grown Obſtinate, Inveterate, and beyond the Power of Medicines to give Relief, is by conſidering the Cauſe of the Diſeaſe, to preſcribe Medicines that are proper to remove it.

If Wind is the Cauſe, Carminative Clyſters are exhibited, to diſcuſs it and moderate the violent Pains in the Stomach cauſed by it: And if the Wind be accompanied with fluſhings in the Face and exceſſive Heat, Spirit of Nitre dulciſied with Spirit of Wine, and impregnated with the Vertue of Carminative Simples after Sylvius's Method, is ſaid to be an incomparable Remedy. Inveterate acid Belchings are put off, by five or ſix Pepper Corns being taken every Morning Faſting. If the Wind proceed from a thick, ſtubborn Mucilage, Aſthmatical Syrups, and Michael's Elixir for the Stomach are very proper; to which you may add Externally, Fomentations with Oil of Chamomel, and of the Carminative Seeds: Or with a mixture of Aniſeed-Water, Spirit of Wine Camphorated and Treacle.

If a Viſcous ſtinking, or otherwiſe offenſive matter be caſt up by Vomit, and there be ſuſpicion that the Cauſe lies in the Cavity of the Stomach, 'tis proper to give a gentle Vomit, of Wine of Squills, or of Salt of Vitriol; or the offending Humours may be purg'd off by Stool, by Stomachical Catharticks adapted pro re nata. But if the Matter ſticks deeply and firmly within the Membranes, or foldings of the Nerves, Diaphoreticks or Specificks that
moderate the efferveſcencies of the Salts are more prevalent, and ought to be adminiſtred at proper times, as the Phyſician employ'd • hall find occaſion: Not forgetting, twice or thrice a Day to apply Fomentations to the Region of the Stomach, with Woolen Cloths dipt in the warm'd Liquid Medicine laſt above named, and wrung forth; for that will much contribute to the abatement of the Patient's griping, intolerable Pains.

In the next place it will be expected that here I ſhould ſay ſomething of a Stomachical Cholick cauſed by Worms gnawing the Tunicles of the Stomach, but I ſhall wholly omit it at preſent; becauſe the next Phyſical Diſcourſe I ſhall publiſh, ſhall be a Treatiſe of the Worms, which I am now preparing for the Preſs. In the mean time, if any Perſon, Young or Old, that is troubled with them, and deſires to be rid of thoſe Vexations and dangerous Inmates, that render Life ſo uneaſy, if he pleaſe to come or ſend to me, he may be ſupplied with Antivermetick Medicines of my own preparing, that will effectually Eject thoſe vile Inhabitants, under every denomination.

The Author's own Medicines.But to return from this Digreſſion, the Method I have ſhewn in the general practice of Phyſick, by the beſt Phyſicians of the preſent Age, in the foregoing Paragraphs, is what I obſerve my ſelf, tho' the Medicines I give are entirely of my own Inventing, Compounding and Preparing, and the Efficacy whereof I can rely upon for a Cure, (if curable) of this dangerous Diſeaſe; for tho' in all Cholical Diſtempers my Elixir, Cholick-Water, Pills and Electuary, will have their Turns, yet am I not unprovided of other
Medicines to aſſiſt effectually in the Cure, When the Cholick is complicated with other Diſeaſes, and conſequently indigitates the uſe of others, as the Cholick varies in its Name, Cauſe and Parts affected.

For theſe Reaſons and becauſe in Stomachical Cholicks, proceeding from Viſcous ſtinking Matter lodg'd in the Cavity of the Stomach, a Vomit ſeems abſolutely neceſſary, to diſlodge the offending Humour; I am always provided of an Emetick of ſuch an univerſal Vertue, that it anſwers all the Intentions of Nature and Art in Vomiting, and leaves no Relicks for another Invaſion behind it. Which Medicine will never loſe its Vertue, and conſequently may be ſent to the remoteſt parts of the Ʋniverſe, and private Families may keep it by them to uſe when they have occaſion.

Where the corrupted Matter in a Stomachical Cholick ſticks firm and deep within the Membranes or Foldings of the Nerves, and indigitates the uſe of Diaphoreticks, or ſuch Medicines as moderate the efferveſcencies of the Salts: For thoſe purpoſes I have a Mineral Remedy, which I exhibit ſometimes in Powder, other whiles in the form of an Electuary, and at other times in a Decoction or Syrup, as they beſt agree with the Patient's Palate, which works almoſt miraculouſly in this Diſeaſe, and ſo cleanſe, purify and ſtrengthen the Stomach, and aſſiſt it in the Work of Fermentation, that it expels all noxious humours whatever, and retains what conduces to a vigorous conſtitution and a durable ſtate of Health.

Theſe great things I am ſenſible my numerous Enemies, which are chiefly Perſons
of my own Profeſſion, or ſuch unthinking People as are prejudiced by their malicious falſe ſtories, will call idle, vain Boſting, but thoſe that have experienced and tried my Medicines, will do m • juſtice in a modeſter and juſter Character, and eſteem my Remedies as Non-Pareils.

The Hyſterical Cholick.This Diſeaſe being commonly known by the tormenting Pains that always accompany it, might reaſonably ſave me the labour of giving, and my Reader the loſs of time in peruſing them: However, in compliance with my Promiſe, I ſhall give him one of the many Obſervations I have made, and Examples I am able to produce.

John Gregory Cabinet-Maker, in Philip-Lane, in the Pariſh of St. Alphage, near London-Wall, being grieved with the Cholick in his Stomach, attended with extraordinary Pain in the Enſiformis, or lower part of the Breaſt Bone; which was ſufficient reaſon to induce me to be of Opinion, that the upper Orifice of the Stomach was affected; and giving him proper Medicines of my own, he no ſooner took them according to my Directions, but he found eaſe immediately, and continuing the uſe of them a very ſhort time, he was reſtored to his former Health, and was able to follow his Buſineſs, which he was uncapable of doing for Five Months time, before he applied himſelf to me, tho' he had taken many Medicines of others, without receiving any Benefit by them; but now enjoys perfect Health, the only comfort of Life.

This Diſeaſe, called by the Greeks 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , and by the Latins Ʋteri Stangulatio
or Colica Hyſtericalis, the Hiſterical Cholick, or Fits of the Mother, is not to be imputed to the Aſcent or Riſing of the Womb, according to the vulgar expreſſion: Nor to the Impetuous ruſhing of the Blood into the Lungs; for the effect truly called Hyſterical, is chiefly and primarily Convulſive, and depends principally on the Brain and genus Nervoſum being affected, and is produced by the exploſion of the Animal Spirits as are other Convulſive Motions, and whatever diſorder or irregularities happen elſe about the motion of the Blood they are only Secondary and depend on the Convulſions of the Viſcera. Nor is this Diſeaſe only frequent, but ſo ſtrangely various, that it reſembles almoſt all the Diſeaſes poor Mortals are inclin'd to, and generally ends in an Hemiplegy, a Palſey on one ſide, below the Head, which obſtructs the Animal Spirits in their paſſage, and is exactly like an Appoplexy; whereby corpulent and old People are deſtroyed, becauſe the Cortex of the Brain is ſtopt by a ſuper abundance of Phlegm. In the violent Convulſions that happen in an Hyſterical Cholick, Women ſeem to have the Falling Sickneſs, and ſometimes ſtruggle ſo violently, that tho' at other times their Strength is but ordinary, they can ſcarce be held by all the united Strength of thoſe that are about them.

Pathognomick Symtoms.The Symptoms of this Diſeaſe are various and manifold, and ſeldom agree in divers Women, or happen wholly in the ſame manner: The moſt common are, Malignant Vapours, exceſſive ſtretching or tearing Pain under the ſhort Ribs, a motion in the lower part of the Belly, and an Aſcent, as it were,
of ſome round thing there, falſly imputed to the Womb, then a Belching or ſtraining to Vomit, a diſtention of the Hypocondres, and a rumbling with a Belching forth of Wind, an uneven and for the moſt part ſhort Breath, a Suffocation in the Throat, a Giddineſs, an, inverſion or rolling of the Eyes, often Laughing or Weeping or Talking Idly; ſometimes a ſpeechleſsneſs and Immobility, with an obſcure or no Pulſe, and a Cadaverous Countenance. Women of all Ages and Conditions are Obnoxious to this Diſeaſe, Rich and Poor, Virgins, Wives, Widows, and ſometimes thoſe Symptoms appear in Girls before Puberty, and ſometimes in Old Woman after their Menſes are ceaſed; and ſome learned Phyſicians tells us, that even Men are ſometimes troubled with ſuch kind of Paſſions. But,

Tho' the Hyſterical Cholick often riſes from the Brain, yet ſometimes it comes by a Cauſe beginning either in the Womb, or in other parts or the Viſcera, and in whatever part it ſeats it ſelf, it preſently produces ſuch Symptoms as belong to it, and unleſs the Phyſician is very Skilful, he will be miſtaken, and think thoſe Symptoms come from ſome Eſſential Diſtemper of this or that Part, and not from an Hyſterick Cholick; therefore the Symptoms are beſt taken from the Part affected. But among all the Diagnoſtick Signs of an Hyſterical Cholick, this is moſt proper and almoſt inſeparable, viz. an Ʋrine as clear as Rock-Water, which Hyſterical Women evacuate moſt plentifully, and is in almoſt all of them the Pathognomick Sign of this Diſeaſe, which we call H • ſterical in Women and Hypocondriacal in Men; and Women and
Men ſeldom Recover, till the Citron colour'd Urine returns to its Amber colour.

Prognostick Symptoms.If the Female Patient, is extraordinarily troubled with Cholick griping Pains and inceſſant Vomitings, joined with ſtrong Convulſive Fits, her Menſes ſtopt, undergoing violent Contractions and Convulſions, about the parts of the Mouth, and Face, and Arms, and Legs, with a Pale, Wan Countenance and trembling as ſhe walks, and growing every Day worſe than other, her Caſe is very Dangerous and ſeldom or never admits of Cure: But if the Convulſions ceaſe, by adminiſtring proper Medicines, adapted to Cholick Pains and Fits of the Mother in Conjunction; Vapours aſcending from the Womb are expell'd, and the Menſes orderly flow, they are hopeful Indications.

The Procatartick or External Cauſes of this complicated Diſeaſe,Cauſes of an Hyſterical Cholick. are violent motions of the Body, or which is oftner and worſe, violent Perturbations of the Mind from ſome ſudden aſſault, either of Anger or Grief, or ſuch like Paſſions, eſpecially as I have ſaid already, if Ʋrine clear as Chriſtal evacuated copiouſl at ſome certain times, makes the Diagnoſtick more manifeſt. But to theſe Diſorders of the Mind, which are uſually the Cauſe of this Diſeaſe, Emptineſs of the Stomach by reaſon of long Faſting, is to be added, and immoderate Bleeding, a Vomit or Purge that has wrought too much. Now having drawn the Picture of this Diſeaſe, according to its vulgar Phenomena; in the next place, the Internal, Efficient Cauſes are to be conſidered, as well as I can gather them from all the Circumſtances joined together: And in my Opinion this Diſeaſe that I call
an H • ſterical Cholick, proceeds from a ſtoppage of the Menſes, a confuſion of the Animal Spirits, when too many of them, and contrary to due proportion are violently burried upon this or that part, cauſing Convulſions and Pains, when they ruſh upon Parts of Exquiſite Senſe; to which the cauſes of a Simple Cholick being added, you have the true Cauſes of this Diſeaſe.

The general method for the Cure of this Diſeaſe, is, firſt to give preſent Eaſe in the Paroxiſms, and then proceed to a Cure. To accompliſh both theſe Intentions, 'tis uſual in the firſt place to apply ſtinking and ſtrong ſmelling things to the Noſtrils, the Effluvia's of which, repreſs and reduce to order the Spirits which are grown too Wild, and apt to make exorbitant efforts; nay, and diſcuſs their Heterogeneous combination, and often wholly exterminate it. Aſſa Faetida, Caſtoreum, Galbanum, tyed in a fine Cloth and held to the Noſtrils are proper; alſo Partridges Feathers, or old Shoes burnt, or Sulphur kindled; alſo the Spirit and Oil of Soot and Harts-horn often give Eaſe; but the chief Indication in this Diſeaſe, is to ſtrengthen the Blood which is the fountain of the Spirits; which being done, the invigorated Spirits can preſerve that order which is agreeable to the Oeconomy of the whole Body, and the particular Parts. And therefore when the Ataxy of the Spirits has vitiated the Humours by long continuance, you muſt firſt leſſen the Humours ſo corrupted, by bleeding and Purging if the Patient has ſufficient strength, before you endeavour to invigo
• ate the Blood; and which indeed you can
ſcarce do, whilſt a faeculent heap of Humours lye in the way.

If there be room for a Vomit, you muſt always begin with that, eſpecially in Cacoch • mical Perſons in whom a mighty load of Viſcous Phlegm ſticking to the Folds and Coats of the Stomach, hinders the Vertues of other Medicines. In a few Days after the Vomit, unleſs ſomewhat indicates the contrary; in Women of a Hot Temperament open a Vein in the Arm preſently, or afterward if need be take Blood from the Foot, or the Fundament by Leeches, and after theſe Evacuations duly performed: always provided they be indicated, let a Purge be given three or four Mornings after. Then to ſtrengthen the Blood, and conſequently ſupport the Spirits, let Chalybeates be exhibited to raiſe a Volatile Ferment in the Vapid and Languid Blood, that the Spirits may be rouſed, which before were preſs'd down by their own Weight. Theſe Directions I think ſufficient, without preſcribing particular Medicines or their Doſes, for he that does not underſtand what Medicines are proper, in every Diſeaſe, the quantity to be given, and the manner How, and the time When, is unfit to practiſe Phyſick; and for thoſe who do not pretend to that Skill, they may have experimented Medicines of me in moſt Diſeaſes, if they either pleaſe to come themſelves, or ſend their Caſes in Writing, or by an Intelligent Meſſenger.

For the Hyſterical Cholick, I have ſuch excellent and effectual Remedies, the knowledge and uſe where of God and Nature has freely beſtowed on me, and daily produce
ſuch wonderful Effects by their own Native Goodneſs and Efficacy, that I ſhould be wanting in my gratitude to God, unjuſt to my ſelf and injurious to the Diſeaſed part of Mankind, not to make them known to the inquiſitive World, ſince I don't pretend to a multiplicity of Medicines, or to more Art than others of my own Profeſſion, tho I take more care than ſome others of my my own Profeſſion do in preparing them and in poſſeſſing my ſelf of ſuch Medicines as are fit, not to palliate, but to cure Diſeaſes, ſpeedily, ſafely and thoroughly. Among which in the Cure of this Diſeaſe and Vapours which attend it, I have a particular Secret that has been experienc'd to excel all others, that I have either heard, or read of, in the whole Republick of Phyſick; as I can prove by abundance of Inſtances, tho' I give here but a few.

Frances Maſh, dwelling next Houſe to the Sign of the Three Travellers in Kent-ſtreet, Southwark, being ſo violently afflicted with a Hyſterick Cholick, that it was thought it would have been her Death; upon taking my Remedies, which I freely gave her, becauſe ſhe was but in mean Circumſtances, ſhe was perfectly recover'd of her Diſtemper, and deſired it might be publiſhed for the good of all People, who ſuffer under the ſame Diſeaſe.

Mrs. Poulter, dwelling at Mr. Jackſon's a Brick-Layer, in Mercer s-ſtreet, next Door to the Sign of the Angel in Long-Acre, in the Pariſh of St. Martin's in the Fields, being ſore grieved with a Cholick and Vapours, inſomuch that her painful Fits continued ſeveral
Nights together, to that degree that he • Life was deſpair'd of by all that viſited her being thought paſt recovery; but applyin • her ſelf to me, and God giving a Ble • ſin • to my Medicines, ſhe was perfectly c •• ed and continues in as good Health as ever ſh • enjoyed in her whole Life, tho' ſhe has no • taken any Medicines for Eight or Te • Months laſt paſt.

A Gentlewoman of good Reputation, is, fo • the Publick good, ready and willing to atteſt the Truth of Two remarkable and e •
traordinary Cures, perform'd by taking m • Medicines; one, upon her Father, who w •• ſeverely afflicted with the Cholick ariſing fro •
Hypocondriack Effects, which is the ſame Diſeaſe in Men as Hyſterical are in Women, an • the other on her Daughter, which was purely Cholical the Stone, and Hyſterical, whoſ • Caſes were both thought very dangerous, b • ſome eminently Learned Phyſicians, wh • attempted their Cure, but without Succeſs who afterwards following my Directions i • taking my Remedies, had the benefit of a • abſolute Cure. If any Perſons deſire it, 〈◊〉 ſhall direct them to the Gentlewoman's Habitation, who will ſatisfy them of the Trut •
of what is above aſſerted.

Mary Wats, dwelling in Noble-ſtreet, nea •
Goldſmiths-Hall, being ſeized with the Ston • and an Hyſterick Cholick, which kept her almoſ • in continued Pains, at times for Ten Year • together, and was thought by her ſelf and others incurable, by giving her my Medicines appropriated to that Diſtemper, ſhe had Relief and an abſolute Cure.

And ſince Experience ſhews, that ſtoppage of the Menſes, or ſuppreſſion of the Courſes, is one of the Cauſes of a Hyſterick Cholick; I cannot here forbear to acquaint the World, that I am poſſeſs'd of a Pouder, of a long, Curious and Chargeable Preparation, which never fails to Cure that Diſtemper, whether in Women, cauſed by the Veins of the Matrix being obſtructed, ſo that the ſuperfluous Blood which nature ordain • d to be evacuated that way, having not a free Paſſage, returns to the greater Veſſels, and is circulated with be whole Maſs of Blood and Humours, by which they are in time vitiated, to the great prejudice of the Womans Health, in being the Original Cauſes of ſeveral other Diſeaſes as well as the Hyſterick Cholick. Or if theſe Obſtructions happen to Virgins, and then is called the Green-ſickneſs, the White-Fever and the White Jaundice, becauſe the native colour in ſuch Perſons is very Pale; yet a few Grains of this Pouder taken according to my Directions, will infallibly cure all thoſe Diſeaſes, as all that try it will happily Experience: And for cleanſing the Womb, and furthering Conception in Barren Women, there is not the like Medicine (I believe) in the World.

The Scorbutick Cholick. Colica Scorbuticus, or the Scorbutick Cholick. There's a ſort of Cachexy reigning in our Northern Clymats, whoſe Symptoms chiefly appearing in the Hypochondria, is called the Hypocondriack Evil, and when its Symptoms are very fierce and exalted, 'tis named the Scurvy: An Apellation given it by the Saxons in North Germany, who are generally afflicted with it. 'Tis a buſie, intermedling, encroaching Diſeaſe, that now mingles almoſt
