with all Chronical Diſtempers, and paſſes inconceivably into all parts of the Body; which cauſed Helmant to ſay of complicated Effects, that per ignorata ſeminaria, & initia inviſibilia, by unknown Seminaries, and in viſible Beginnings, which is certainly true, for in theſe latter times new Diſeaſes have ſtarted up, which were unknown to the Antients; becauſe they have put on other ſtrange Symptoms and Properties, Quibus larvati incedunt, with which they walk diſguiſed and deceive ſuch Phyſicians, as think to Cure Diſeaſes by following the Directions and Precepts of the Antients, who knew little or nothing of the unaccountable Mixtures, Complications and Diſguiſes, which we daily ſee; and yet ſome are ſo ſottiſh to confine themſelves to ſuch ſuperannuated exploded Definitions, Notions and Medicines as they have left us, who practiſed when Diſeaſes were but few, more ſingle, calm and gentle, and more tractable and curable than at this Day, when its rare to ſind an uncomplicated Diſeaſe, in which the Blood and other Humours are not vitiated, by being unhappily mix'd with other unſeen Maladies.

Now becauſe the Scurvy is a lurking Diſeaſe, and conſumes the Patient by inſenſible or ſlow degrees, and its direful effects are never ſo much perceived or felt, as when it intermixes it ſelf with other Diſeaſes, ſo its ſeldom regarded as the principal Offender, but the the Diſeaſe is chiefly attributed to the Concommitant Diſtemper that cauſes Pain. So it often happens, that a continued latent Scurvy is little obſerved, but when its joined with the Cholick that cauſes griping tormenting Pains, the Diſeaſe is called a Cholick,
and Remedies uſed accordingly without Succeſs, becauſe the Scurvy was neglected, tho' ſcarce any effect requires a more ſpeedy Phyſical help, than the Cholick and Gripes of the Beſly occaſion'd by the Scurvy, which makes them more violent, and of longer continuance, by obſtinately reſiſting the Methods of Cure.
In the Symptoms of the Scorbutick Cholick, Symptoms of the Scorbutick Cholick. I ſhall be very brief, having been very large on that Head in the foregoing Cholicks.

The uſual Signs are, high colour'd Urine or precipitating a Red Sandy Fleſh colour'd Sediment, or faſtens red friable Sand upon the ſides of the Urinal. Continual Pain of the Head, Palpitation of the Heart, puffing up of the Stomach, loathing, Vomiting, Belching, Hiccough, Cough, Tumors and Putrefaction of the Gums with much Spitting; Looſeneſs and blackneſs of the Teeth, (for the Cure of which I have a Dentefrice which makes the Teeth as White as Ivory,) the Breath ſtinks, and is ſometimes fetch'd with great difficulty, and is ſeldom free from terrible Pains of the Cholick, and trembling and looſeneſs of the Joints and Limbs, with Lazineſs and often Faint Sweats; there is alſo ſometimes Malignant Ʋlcers, dry hard Tubercles, Eriſipelas, and Oedematous Tumors, with many others, which to enumerate, were to comprehend an univerſal Genus of Atoms within a very narrow Limitation.

This Diſeaſe is very hard to cure, where the Scorbutick Humour is obdurate and predominant, and when the Cure has been too long delayed, or not treated as a complicated Diſeaſe, many times 'tis very Dangerous, the Pains of the Cholick may run into an incurable
Iliack Paſſion, and its ſullen Companion, may bring a Dropſie, a Conſumption, or other Mortal Chronical Diſtempers, and ſometimes Acute Diſeaſes, as the Appoplexy Swooning, or the like; which produce ſudden Death.

Cauſes of a Scorbutick Cholick.The Immediate cauſes of this Diſeaſe, is, a volatile Acid, that irritates the Nerves and Membranes, ſharpens the Lympha, debauches the innate Spirits of the Parts, and perverts the equal temperature of the Blood. The Remote Cauſes, are, Sea Air impregnated with Salin, Acid Vapours, Salt and Viſcous Food, Lazineſs, Weakneſs of Digeſtion, Infection, a Hereditary Conveyance, and the influence of Chronical Diſeaſes. If the Diſeaſe is recent it admits of Cure. If inveterate, it requires a continued uſe of proper Medicines for a long ſpace of time.

Cure of a Scorbutick Cholick.The Cure of a Scorbutick Cholick, conſiſts, in correcting and evacuating the Crudities of the firſt Paſſages, fortifying the Stomach, retrieving the due Craſis of the Blood, reſtoring all wonted Evacuations to their former Courſe, and to appeaſe excruciating Pains. In order then to compaſs theſe Ends, and Cure this ſtubborn and rebellious Diſeaſe, the Sick muſt obſerve a good Diet, without which Phyſical means will profit but little: And here, becauſe in the firſt place there will be a neceſſity (if poſſible) to give Eaſe in the Fit by Opiates, let them always be accompanied by Antiſcorbutick Specificks, of which may be prepared diverſity of good Medicines, both Chymical and Galenical. The Volatile Salts both of Animals and Vegitables are excellent to open all Obſtructions, and Temper the Humours; alſo, Elixir Proprietatis, the Spirit of Sal Armoniack, the Spirit
of Nitre, and of Salt Dulcified, Salt of Steel, Wormwood and Tartar, Oil of Juniper, Cloves and Cinamon, are all Antiſcorbutick Specificks.

Next in order are gentle Laxitives, eſpecially in Hot Conſtitutions; ſuch are Pills of Armoniacum, or thoſe of Tartar mix'd with ſweet Mercury, to prevent or take away Coſtiveneſs. Reſinous Purgatives are to be avoided, as beings endow'd with an Aſtringent Quality. Raiſins, Prunes, Tamarinds, and Ripe ſweet Apples, or their expreſs'd Juice are of conſiderable Efficacy in this Caſe; but Sugar and other ſweet things ought to be carefully avoided. Rhubarb or Cream of Tartar, ſharpened with Pouder of Jalap, are proper for ſuch as are of a Moiſt Juicy Conſtitution.

The Patient's Body being thus prepared, you ought to proceed to Alteratives, ſuch are Steel and all fix'd Salts, or whatever ſubdues an Acid. To which join Aperient, Diureticks and bitter Stomachical Aromaticks, or the Spirituous Volatile Salts, Mynſichts Arcanūm Duplicatum, is of excellent uſe, eſpecially when the Sick is troubled with Fluſhings and ſudden Inflamations. Elixir Proprietatis prepared with an Acid and mix'd with the Spirit of Scurvigraſs, and that of Sal Armoniac is alſo proper. The Tincture of Tartar mix'd with the Spirit of Sal-Armoniack, and given by degrees to Forty Drops, is a celebrated Medicine. And as you find occaſion, Fomentations, Ligatures, Ventoſes, Sternutatories, &c. are of uſe.

I have been long you ſee in diſcourſing the Cure of the Scorbutick Cholick, according to the general Method of Practice, becauſe its
a ſtubborn Diſeaſe, and too often of long continuance: Occaſion'd by this Diſeaſe, being, as it were, an odd and new kind of Diſtemper, not reducible to the old Claſs of Cholicks. Secondly being not conſider'd in its various Mixtures, Complications and Diſguiſes, which requires other ſorts of Medicines to cure it, than are commonly preſcribed. Thirdly by Practioners being confounded by variety of Medicines directed by Authors, who ſeeing one Medicine fail, run to another, and ſo from Medicine to Medicine in an endleſs Circuit, till they have either deſtroy'd or nauſeated their Patients, as well as cram'd their Chamber-Windows and Tables, with Galipots, Glaſſes, Boxes and Papers, whoſe Contents, inſtead of expelling noxious Humours, had no other effect than draining the Patient's Purſe to enrich an unexperienc'd, unskilfull Phyſician.

Now theſe Evils, almoſt grown a common Nuſance to the Publick, as well as a Reproach to Phyſitians, are remedied, by thoſe few Men, of which number, I profeſs my ſelf to be One, that make Art follow Nature, rather than ſtrain Nature and her Anomalies to general Rules of Art, and who ſeeing Nature degenerated into Extravagancies and complicated Diſeaſes, unknown to the Ancients, endeavour to find out Experienc'd ways to deal with her, however various and diſguiſed, and by red cing a whole Apothecary's Shop into a few well ſtudied and often Experienc'd Medicines; ſuch Men tho' falſely called Empericks, will be Maſters in the Art of Phyſick ſince they can truly ſay with Ovid Remed. Am. l. 2.

q.p: Et quoniam vaniant Morbi, variabimus Artes Mille Mali ſpecies, Mille ſalutis erunt.
q.l: Becauſe Diſeaſes mix and vary, therefore we
Do vary Arts of Cure; and tho' there be
A Thouſand ſorts of ſtrange Diſtempers ſteal
On us, we have moſt certain ways to heal.

div.p: This being the main and honeſt deſign of Practiſing, it will be no ſtrange thing to believe, that I being bred an Apothecary and having ſeen the ineffectual Preſcription and multiplicity of Medicines uſed by other Men, and dedicating my Life to the Service of Mankind, in the Knowledge and Practice of Phyſick, that I ſhould by Converſation, much reading of the beſt Authors, Foreign and Domeſtick, and by almoſt a Twenty Years Practice, be able to ſhorten the number of Medicines and contract them into a few; but ſo efficacious in their Nature and Effects, as render them effectual in moſt Diſeaſes, and ſuch I aſſure you I have for the Cure of this Contumacious Diſeaſe, the Scorbutick Cholick; of which I could give you numerous Examples of Perſons cured by them, as well as in theſe few, that follow, who have given me leave to make uſe of their Names, and Places of Abode: Of which I ſee I muſt be more ſparing for the future, becauſe the Book begins to ſwell into a larger Volume than I firſt intended.

Elizabeth the late Wife of Robert Miles, Tobacconiſt, in Lamb-Alley, in Abchurch-Lane, was for ſome Years troubled with a Complication of Diſeaſes, viz. the Scorbutick
Cholick, Rheumatiſm, Sciatica, Palſey, Gravil in the Kidneys, and very troubleſome Vapours, living in ſo miſerable a Condition, that ſhe was left off by ſeveral Practioners as Incureable, and thought to be even at the very Brink of the Grave; but being committed to my Gare, thro' the bleſſing of God upon the uſe of my Medicines, I cured her of her complicated Diſtempers to that Degree, that ſhe comfortably attends her daily Affairs, and enjoys a better ſtate of Health that ſhe had done for Six Years laſt paſt. The truth whereof ſhe is ready and willing to atteſt upon Oath before a Magiſtrate, as ſhe has done to me in a Certificate under her Hand.

Mr. William Bagley, Cloth-Worker, i •
Miles's-Alley, in Petticoat-Lane, was afflicte • with a Rhuematiſm, complicated with Scorbutick Cholick Pains, for Four Years ſucceſſively at Spring and Fall; a lameneſs in hi • Hands and Feet, with large Knobs and Swellings, was cured by the uſe of my Medicines, and has continued in firm Health without any Symptoms of a Relaps, or the return of Pain for a long ſpace of time, as h • will ſatisfy any Perſon that enquires 〈◊〉 him.

William Weſt Senior, Waterman, dwellin • near St. Saviour's-Mill-Stairs, in Southwar •
was violently afflicted with a Scorbutick Cholick, joined with Nephritick Pains, vulgarl • called the Stone Cholick, and receiving 〈◊〉 help from others, addreſs'd himſelf to m •• and I at a ſmall charge, and in little tim • caſed him of his terrible griping Pains, ar •
brought away Three large Stones. In gratitude for which Cure, he recommended ſeveral of his Neighbours to me, who were troubled with the like Diſeaſe, who all, as well as himſelf were cured, to their great ſatisfaction.

The Iliack Paſſion.I his Diſeaſe called in Greek 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 in Latin Iliaca Paſſio, from the Gut Ileon, which is chiefly affected in this Diſtemper, is a Cholick in exceſs, an extream Coſtiveneſs, pain about the Navel, riſing from the inverted Periſtaltick motion of the Guts, diſgorging the Excrements upward; for the Fibres of the Guts which ought to be contracted from •• e Superior towards the Inferior, are drawn to the Superior; ſo whatſoever is contained in the Guts is Vomited up, and Clyſters how ſharp ſo ever become Vomitive: Purges alſo taken by the Mouth are caſt up by Vomit; and I am of Opinion, that the exquiſite and intollerable Pain coming upon this Diſeaſe, is only occaſion'd by the aforeſaid Prepoſterous motions of the Guts; for as thoſe Folds which the many Circumvolutions of the Guts make, are ſo formed by Nature, that they ſhould moſt aptly conduce to the carrying, down of the Feces; when they are forced to give way to a motion contrary to their Fibres, the aforeſaid Pain is occaſion'd from thence, which is fix'd to one Part, and is like the boaring of an Augur, when either the value, which is ſeated at the beginning of the Colon, hinders the going back of the Excrements to the Ilium, or any other Membrane belonging to the Sinus, ſuſtains alone the force of this Periſtaltick motion.

Symptoms of an Iliack Paſſion.The Signs of an approaching Iliack Paſſion, are, extream Coſtiveneſs, retraction of the Anus, a Loathing, Vomiting and intollerable Pains in the ſmall Guts; and if a Hiccough follow it, threatens Death. If the Anus is much drawn back, ſo that a Clyſter-Pipe cannot enter it, 'tis a ſign that the groſs Intestiness are affected. If otherwiſe the ſmall Guts are touched. If the greateſt Pain poſſeſſes the Epigaſtrium, the Ilium is moſt oppreſs'd. A ſhooting burning Pain in one particular part of the Body, a Lipyria Fever. If the Pain ceaſing is attended by cold Sweats, difficult Reſpiration, Swoonings, and ſometimes Convulſions, 'tis a Sign of a Gangrene, cauſed by the corrugation of the Guts, miſtaken by ſome for a twiſting of 'em round one another, a thing inconſiſtent with their Ligation to the Meſentery. In fine, the common Symptoms of an Iliack Paſſion, are hardneſs of the Belly, ſuppreſſion of the Ʋrine, Loathing, Vomiting, firſt the contents of the Stomach, and next the Excrements, a ſtinking habit of Body, frequent Swoonings, inſufferable griping Pains in the Guts, a prodigious Anxiety, and ſometimes Vomiting of Clyſters.

Prognoſtick Signs.In the Prognoſticks of an Iliack Paſſion, • nflamations or Gangreenes are Mortal. If the upper Gut deſcend in the lower 'tis a fatal Symptom. If the lower aſcend into the higher, 'tis curable. If the Diſeaſe proceed from a Rupture or hardened Excrements, 'tis not deſperate. If Sleep ſucceeds the taking of Opiates, 'tis a hopeful Indication. Deafneſs or Dotings are pernicious conſequences. If the Sweat, Breath, and Belching ſtink very much, Death is about to put an End to the Patient's Miſery.

Cauſes of the Iliack Paſſion.The Cauſe of an Ileos, or Iliaca Paſſio, is a excrementitious Viſcous Matter, adhering to the Gut Ileo, which in time is coagulated into a very hard ſubſtance, almoſt in the Form of Bullets, whence all the paſſage for Excrements by ſiege is ſtop'd, and anon their regreſs and aſcent to the Stomach follows, with a miſerable Vomiting of them up.

The Rupture of the Peritoneum may cauſe this grievous Diſeaſe, eſpecially if it be ſo great, that not only the ſmall Guts but the great ones alſo, fall through the lacerated Orifice, and renders them uncapable of being reduced or put back through the ſame Hole; ſo that a hard and unſupportable Tumor follows, which hinders the Reflux of Blood, and cauſes an Inflamation, and conſequently a Gangrene in the Guts, attended with a violent Vomiting of the Excrements and a ſpeedy ſummons to the Grave.

But we may chiefly aſſign a twofold Cauſe of this Inverſion, from whence the Pain ariſes, and they are Obſtruction and Irritation; for whatever violently obſtructs the Inteſtines, ſo that nothing can paſs downwards, neceſſarily occaſions this contrary Motion in them, as hardned Excrements, groſs Wind collected in great quantity, &c. Irritation proceeds from ſharp and Malignant Humours caſt upon the Stomach and Guts that are next to it, by the exceſſive raging of the Blood, by reaſon of a late Fever begun, whereby the motion of the Stomach is firſt Inverted, and violently forced to caſt up what is contained in it; at length the ſmall Guts that are joined to the Stomach being weakned, yield to the violent Motion of it,
and with them at laſt the greater follow by conſent; the Stomach Vomiting beginning the fatal Tragedy: And this may be truly call'd the Iliack Paſſion.

The cure of this Diſeaſe, conſiſts in removing the Irritation, and retrieving the Natural Motion of the Guts, to that end if the Excrements are harden'd they ought to be ſoften'd by the ſpeedy exhibition of Clyſters, before they are hardened beyond Relief. All Purgatives are improper, till the Pain in the Guts and Stomach are quieted, and reſtored to their Natural Motion, which you may know, by a large quantity of Humours being voided downwards by the help of Nature or Art. Opiates are very hurtful in caſe of a Gangrene and in that of Obſtructions, till the Belly is well opened; but if the Diſeaſe proceed from violent Irritations, attended by continual vomiting, Opiates may be mix'd with Stomachical Medicines while the Patient is ſtrong: Always remembring, that whatever you uſe in the Cure of this Diſeaſe, whether outwardly or inwardly, muſt be Warm, both in the Fit, and when the Patient is on the mending hand.

If the Small Guts only are inverted, give Emollient Clyſters, quickned with Sal Gem, or the Infuſion of Crocus Metallorum, or thoſe of the Carminative Seeds boiled in Childs Urine and Water: But if the great ones are alſo Inverted, that ſort of Clyſters are noxious, and you muſt ſeek help from temperate, Laxative, lubrical Potions; ſuch as the Decoction of Emollient Herbs in Broath, mix'd with Oil of Sweet Almonds newly drawn.

When all other Medicines want Succeſs, ſome Men give Leaden Bullets, and boaſt of the uſe of Quickſilver, which I have ſeldom known to have done much good, but often prove injurious, eſpecially in an Inflamation, Rupture, Gangrene, or falling of the upper Gut into the lower; therefore if any Practitioner thinks himſelf under a neceſſity of uſing Quickſilver, which is prefered before Bullets, let him be ſure to prepare his Patient's Body before he gives it, with lubric al Medicines, ſuch as Oil of Sweet Almonds new drawn, or Sperma Caeti: Then exhibit Three, Four, and ſometimes Eight Ounces of purified Quickſilver, together with Oil of Sweet Almonds and Mint Water; and if it does not anſwer his Intentions at firſt, let it be frequently repeated, and the mean while inject Emollient Clyſters, foment the Belly with ſoftning Decoctions; or ſet the Sick into a proper Bath. If the Mercury does not force its way out of the Body, give ſharp Clyſters, and anoint the Belly with Oil of Coloquintida to ſoften the Excrements. If the Quickſilver offend the Mouth, Throat and Gums, check its virulence with a Gargariſm of Honey of Roſes, and Syrup of Violets; and if the Mercury is ſucceſsful in opening the Body, remember to exhibit the Lunar Bezoar and Diaphoretick Antimony, to expel the remains of the Mercury; for tho' Mercury given by an Intelligent Perſon is an Excellent Medicine, yet it always does Miſchief, if any of it ſtays too long in the Body.

Theſe are the uſual Methods for diſcovering the Cauſe and curing this Diſeaſe, which I publiſh in this ſuccinct way; Firſt, to aſſiſt thoſe that want greater Light; Secondly
to ſhew, that I am thoroughly inſtructed in the Knowledge of Phyſick; and, Thirdly, to ſilence Malicious Back-biters, who for want of buſineſs, make it part of their employment, to repreſent me in their ow • Claſs of Ignoramus's which this Treatiſe, a •• the reſt that are to follow it, will plainly confute, in the Opinion of all Men of Senſe, Generoſity and Learning.

In my own Practice for the Cure of this Diſeaſe, when it evidently appears by the Symptoms above-named, and by Vomiting up Clyſters, that its a true Iliack Paſſion, I apply my ſelf to give the Patient ſome Eaſe, if it be poſſible; for let others ſay what they pleaſe, he that can do that has half conquer'd the Diſeaſe, for then Nature will aſſiſt in removing the Cauſe, by being enabled to ſuſtain the Force of Medicines proper to ſoften the Excrements, and after to expel them by Siege: And to this end, I give my Elixir in ſmall Doſes, repeat them often, and enlarge the number of Drops every time they are given, and I never found them unſucceſsful; their Vertue being to invigorate the Sick by giving him a relaxation from his Pain, Mollifying the offending Matter, and by that means preparing and ſmoothing the way for my Pills to drive it out by gentle degrees; for this Diſeaſe will endure no rough and violent Treatment.

Here I cannot, according to Cuſtom, give Examples of Perſons Cured by the uſe of my Two above-named Remedies; (one I cured ſometime ſince, but am not permitted to make uſe of her Name,) for tho', bleſſed be God, I have never wanted Succeſs, yet I could
not prevail with the Patients I have Cured, to give me leave to Name them, and ſo the Credit of my Medicines in this Caſe, can have no other Vouchers but my own Word and Reputation, which I value my ſelf more upon than Ten Thouſand Teſtimonials.

The Caeliack Cholick.Called in Greek 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , in Latin Caeliaca Paſſio, the Caeliack Paſſion, or Caeliack Cholick, is a Looſeneſs of the Belly, when the Meat comes forth crude and imperfectly digeſted; which ſome ſay is not to be refered to the Concoction only being hurt, but to the debility of the Retentive Faculty, the Food being not long enough retained to be Concocted; by which it appears, ſay they, that the Diſeaſe proceeds from a fault in the Stomach as well as in the Guts: But the Learned Etmullerus, ſays, it is a Flux of the Belly, by which the Chyle is voided together with Excrements, the Stomach being in no fault, becauſe Chylification is duly perform'd there; therefore the blame, ſays he, muſt either be laid on the Bile, that is ſtopt in its Paſſage to the Guts, or by degenerating from its Saline Acrimony, and conſequently is unfit to ſeperate the Chyle: Or elſe on the Lacteal Veſſels through which the Chyle ought to paſs, their Orifices being covered With Slime, or ſhut by the Contraction, or Corroſion of the Inteſtines occaſion'd by Fluxes.

Symptoms of a Caeliaca.The Symptoms of this Diſeaſe, are, extraor • inary, Pains both in the upper and lower Region of the Belly, not unattended with Pain in the Back and Limbs; for all complicated Diſeaſes, generally affect all the Neighbouring Parts, as well as the Place where they are more particularly and chiefly ſeated;
and that you may have a true notion of this Maladay, obſerve, that if the Bile is defective, the Excrements are White, or very Pale; without any ſign of ſeparation. If the obſtruction of the Lacteal Veins cauſe the Diſeaſe, the Excrements are Yellowiſh, and the Chyle, tho' voided at the ſame time with them, is but looſely mix'd with them, as being ſeparated in the Guts, but diſappointed in its Paſſage.

Cauſes of a Coaliack Cholick.The Cauſes of this Diſtemper, are generally rank'd under Three Heads, which will comprehend all the differing Opinions about it. The Firſt is a Cold Diſtemper of the Stomach and Liver, which generate Phlegmatick and Glutinous Humours, which cover the Wrincles of the Stomach that it cannot retain the Food: Tho' Retention be made by the Aſtringing Quality, yet it operates by fit Inſtruments, viz. the rawneſs of the Inward Coat of the Stomach; which rawneſs being taken away, and the Wrincles filled by the Humours aforeſaid, the Retention is damnified, and the Food Slips away without Concoction.
The Second Cauſe aſſigned by others, is, violent ſharp Humours, that prick, twinge, and irritate the Parts, by which the Stomach and Guts are provoked to ſend out the Meat too ſoon.

The Third, and which I take to be the true Cauſe of the Caeliack Cholick, is, the Obſtruction of the Meſenteraick Veins which hinder the paſſage of the Chyle to the Liver, or the Obſtruction of the Glandules of the Meſentery, and therefore muſt of neceſſity be ejected by the Belly. If this: Diſeaſe is of long continuance 'tis very dangerous, becauſe
Nature is deprived of her Nouriſhment, and the Weak Body is liable to the Inſults of all Diſeaſes.

Now, ſince the Diſeaſe called 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , a Lientary, is alſo a Flux of the Belly, in which the Food is quickly thrown out of the Body undigeſted; and differs only from a Caeliack Cholick in degrees, and that their Cures are the ſame; I ſhall omit treating particularly on that Head, and refer the Reader to what follows.

Cure of the Caelick Cholick.The Curatory Indication of the Caeliack Choliack, is, to remove the Morbiſick Cauſe, and ſtrengthen the Stomach, which kind of Method being ſeaſonably begun, and duly proſecuted often does the whole Work; for the Cauſe of the Diſeaſe or the Root of it being cut off, the Effects depending on it, die of their own accord. Therefore if the Bile is ſluggiſh, or ſtopp'd in its Paſſage, means muſt be uſed to make it more Active, to correct the Acid and Auſture Ferment proceeding from the Stomach and Inteſtines, to retrieve the Natual Texture and diſtribution of the Bile and to promote the Separation of the Heterogenious Particles. If the Lacteal or Milky Veſſels are ſhut up, endeavour to remove the Slime that choaks them, by attenuating, opening Ingredients, Aſtringents are improper. Let the Peccant humours be purged: After which the Tincture of Tartar, or of the Droſs of Regules of Antimony, or Chalybeate Tinctures, mix'd with the Spirit of Sal Armoniaci, are very convenient to ſtrengthen the Stomach by procuring an Appetite. Amatus Luſitanus highly commends the following Preſcription. Conſerve of Roſes ſix Ounces, Venice Treacle ſix Drams, and Syrup
of Quinces a ſufficient quantity to make an Opiate: Halt an Ounce of which muſt be taken in the Morning, faſting an Hour after it.
For the Uſe and Benefit of my own Patients, I have ſtated and well experienc'd Medicines for the Cure of this Diſeaſe, 〈◊〉 which I could give numerous Examples, tho' I only prodnce Two.

q.l: Experience guides my Practice; others may do,
What their Inclinations prompt them to.

div.p: Mrs. Anne Percival, of Ruſſel-ſtreet Bloomsbury, was for ſeveral Years grieved with a Caeliack Cholick at certain Times and Seaſons only, but about Three Months ſince, ſhe was ſeized with it in ſo violent and terrible a manner, that her Life was deſpair'd of: And having by the Advice of ſome able Phyſicians, taken divers Medicines, without receiving any Benefit by them; at length hearing of my great ſucceſs in curing the Cholick, of what kind ſoever; ſhe came to me, who thro' the Divine Bleſſing, and the uſe of my Medicines, was cured in a ſhort Time. And that others who ſuffer the like cruel Pains, and languiſh under that Diſeaſe, might alſo find Relief, gave me Authority under her Hand writing, to publiſh her Name and Cure. And if any Perſon deſires further Satisfaction in this matter, if they pleaſe to enquire at her Brother's Houſe, Mr. Percival in Benbridge-ſtreet, in the Pariſh of St. Giles's in the Fields, this Fact will be atteſted by Word of Mouth.

Samuel Maynard, dwelling in Lydes Court near St. Giles's Church, being ſorely afflicted with the Cholick, and Rheumatiſm, the Sciaticà, and exceſſive Pains in his Back and Limbs, inſomuch that he was uncapable of following his Employment, was happily cured by my Advice and taking my Remedies, in a very ſhort time, and now is able to follow his Buſineſs as formerly. This Example I inſert, as I could do many others, to ſhew what a concatenation of Diſeaſes and different ſorts of Pains and in many Places do often accompany this Diſeaſe, as will further appear in the next Inſtance.

A ſufficient and reputable Tradeſman's Wiſe, in the City of London, was unſpeakably troubled with Vapours, originally proceeding from this Diſeaſe, which run her into Diſtraction; and after much Advice and taking many Medicines from other Phyſicians, to no purpoſe, her Husband ſent for me, and by Heaven s Bleſſing, my particular Care, and the ſeaſonable Uſe of my Medicines, ſhe was reſtored to her Senſes, perfectly recovered, freed from her Vapours, and ſo continues. So that you ſee violent Pains of the Head, Giddineſs and Frenzies, are concomitants in a Caeliack Cholick. I will direct any modeſt Enquirer, how, and where, they may be ſatisfied of the truth of this remarkable Inſtance from the Gentlewomans own Mouth.

The Cholerick Cholick.This Diſeaſe named in Greek 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 and in Latin Cholerica Paſſio, is a Grier, in which the Vicious Humours are impetuouſly thrown
out both by Vomit and Stool, with a violent Pain in the Stomach and Belly, Diſtenſion of the Hypocondria, Heartburnings, Thirſt, Perplexity of the Breaſt, a ſwift and ſometimes Small Pulſe, frequent Swoonings, a coldneſs in the outward Parts, Proſtration of Strength, and at laſt Convulſions and Hiccoughs. This Diſeaſe, ſome ſay, is a Symptom of the Expulſive Faculty being hurt by uncocted Meats, and if the Retentive Faculty is alſo in fault, the Diſtemper is ſo much the worſe and more violent.

Immediate Cauſes of a Cholerick Cholick.Some make two ſorts of this Diſeaſe, a Wet and a Dry, and from hence came the vulgar Diſtinction of Moiſt and Dry Gripes. A Moiſt is what I am diſcourſing. The Dry is more rarely found, proceeds from a Windy Spirit, produced in the Stomach, by the fiery Heat of the part corrupting the Meat, or by Meats Rank and Windy, as Hipocrates himſelf affirms. Senuertus from the Hermetical Doctrine, adds another cauſe, namely, Salt and aduſt Humours in the H • pochondria, which grow Hot by the mixture of another Humour, and demonſtrates it, by the mixing Aqua Fortis and Oil of Vitriol with Salt of Tartar, which produce very flatuous Spirits: So that according to theſe Authors, the Immediate Cauſes of this Diſeaſe, are, Cholerick, Burnt, Sharp, Salt or Rotten Humours of the Stomach, Bowels, Spleen and Meſentery; or ſome Nouriſhment of a pernicious Quality, or ſome ſtrong Medicine or Poiſon, taken uncorrected.

O •• aſional Cauſes.The Occaſional Cauſes of a Cholerick Cholick, are the ſame with thoſe of a Looſeneſs. The Corruption and Acrimony of Food in the Stomach, the aſſumption of Sharp, Coſtick
Medicines, ſuch as Antimony, Arſenick, Mercury, &c.

If the Excrements are Livid, Faetid, Black, or Corroſive; if it accompany Malignant Fevers, eſpecially in the Beginning, and if the Stomach is much diſordered, it generally proves fatal. 'Tis an Acute Diſeaſe, and quickly finiſhes its Courſe. It obſerves a Tertian Period in its Exaſperations, and frequently relapſes after an apparent Cure.

Symptoms.The Signs preceding this Diſeaſe, are, frequent and plentiful Evacuations of Cholerick, ſharp and corrupted Humours, upward and downward, ſwelling with Wind, Thirſt, and gnawing Pains in the Stomach and Guts: A Loathing, which a little appeas'd with cold Drink, which is ſoon after caſt up. The Pulſe high and unequal, Sweating, with Convulſion of the extreme Parts and Swooning, are dangerous Symptoms. 'Tis eaſily diſcover'd whether the Diſeaſe came by ſome violent Medicine, Poiſon, or offenſive Dyet.

The Internal Cauſes are known by the Quality of the Humours that are ejected. If there be continual Loathing and Gnawing, the Diſeaſe is in the Stomach. If a Malignant Fever is join'd, it is in the Veins. If it has its Original from ſome ill Diet, there is Hopes, that when the peccant Matter is caſt out, the Diſeaſe will end. If its very violent, 'tis dangerous, for the greater the Convulſions, Swoonings, and Coldneſs of the extream Parts are, the nearer Death is at Hand.

In the Beginning of the Cure, you ought to aſſiſt Evacuations with gentle, cooling, and cleanſing Clyſters, eſpecially Milk Clyſters,
with Venice Treacle, or Diaſcordium diſſolved in them are always uſeful. It's proper to breathe a Vein, to cool the burnt and boiled Blood, but let it be done with Diſcretion, Twice or Thrice, if the Strength be not impaired by the Firſt. Endeavour to qualify the ſharpneſs of the Humours after this manner. Waters of Plantane, Purſlane and Mint of each two Ounces: Syrup of Quinces, and dried Roſes, of each one Ounce; Syrup of Vinegary, half an Ounce, mix them, and diſſolve therein two Scruples of Theriack Andromachi, and ſix Drops of Oil of Vitriol: Give now and then a Spoonful. But if the Patient has ſome Eaſe, and if the Symptoms abate or diſappear, take great care that they dont ſuddenly return, to your Amazement and the Deſtruction of the Patient, as it ſometimes happens unforeſeen in this Caſe. Therefore Nouriſh him and Strengthen his Stomach, ſays moſt of our Eminent Phyſicians, with a Reſtoring Opiate, compounded in or after this Method. Gelly of Harts-Horn made with Canary Wine, four Ounces, Conſerve of Roſes, Burrage, Bugloſs and Clove Gilly-Flowers, of each one Ounce: Confectio Alkermes, half an Ounce, Citron Bark and Nutmegs, Candied, of each three Drams; Eſſence of Cloves, Mace, Nutmegs and Cinamon, of each three Drops, and with the Syrup of Clove Gilly-Flowers make On Opiate; of which muſt be taken the quantity of a Hazle Nut or more, Mornings and Evenings. Of all the Medicines uſed againſt Looſeneſs, ſays a great Author, Opium is the chief, being a powerful controler of all tumultuous Motions and accordingly preſcribes Laudanum Opiatum, or Liquid Laudanum in large quanties, for the Cure of this and moſt other Diſeaſes.

But for my part, tho' I won't pretend to cenſure the Practice of my Superiors, yet I think my ſelf obliged to ſay, that I tamper not with Opiates, nor ever uſe Laudanum but on extraordinary occaſions, being rather a Pallative than a Curative Medicine; and therefore in my Practice for the Cure of this or any other Diſeaſe I pretend to Cure, I only employ my own Experiencd Medicines, which by their own native vertue ſubdue Diſeaſes by their amicable correſpondence with Nature, and by aſſiſting her in all her Operations and endeavours, to ſupport her ſelf, and exterminate thoſe noxious Invaders, that diſturb her deſired Peace and tranquility. And that I have ſuch efficacious Remedies for the Cure of this Diſeaſe, if timely conſulted, will appear by the following Examples.

An Eminent Trader in the City of London, who had for a long time been grieviouſly troubled with intollerable Pains proceeding from a Cholerick Cholick, ſuch as violent Pains in the Stomach and Bowels, diſtenſion of the Hypochondria, Heart burning, Thirſt and perplexity of the Breaſt; inſomuch that he ſcarce enjoyed one Minutes Health, and having adviſed with the Learned, and taken a Multiplicity o • Medicines both inwardly and by outward applications to his Breaſt, to his very great trouble, but without Relief, he was at laſt recommended to me, and I perfectly cured him in a few Days, no Symptoms of the ſaid Diſeaſe having appeard, ſince the time of his Recovery; and tho' he is unwilling to have his Name expoſed in Print, yet to do me and

Mr. John Shadwel, near the Sign of the Three Mariners, in the Pariſh of St. Thomas Wapping, Mate of a Merchant Man, having been a long Voyage, and feeding much upon Meat that had been long ſalted, at his comming on ſhore, was violently taken with frequent vomiting and Purging, attended with great Weakneſs of Body, a chilneſs in the outward Parts and unexpreſſible Pain. He conſulted two Phyſicians, took the Medicines they jointly preſcribed, but thoſe Gentlemen being frighted at the appearance of a ſlight convulſive Motion in the Patients Face and Eyes, gave him over as Incurable: Whereupon I was ſent for, and by the Bleſſing of God upon one ſingle Medicine, he had Eaſe in leſs than Ten Minutes time, and continuing the ſame Medicine but four Days together, was perfectly Recovered, and ſo remains to this Day.

The Dyſentery or Bloody Flux.A Dyſentery, which the Greeks name 〈 in non-Latin alphabet 〉 , properly ſo called, proceeds from the Ulceration of the Inteſtines, but is commonly taken for every Bloody Flux: The Latins call it Tormina from the exceſſive Pain the Patient endures. This Diſeaſe which is voiding Blood and purulent Matter with tormenting Pain, is diſtinguiſhd from the Painleſs Evacuation of Thin, Watery Blood from the internal Hemerroid Veinsm, called by the Ancients a Flux of the Liver,
and likewiſe from the Natural diſcharge of Blood independent of the Guts, causd by its redundancy in the Body, as after Amputation, ſuppreſſion of the Menſes, &c. or by its Acrimony opening the Veſſels, or the Obſtruction of the Bowels hindering its regular Circulation. Agreeable hereunto, Galen mentions four kind of Fluxes, all which he calls Dyſenteries. The firſt is when any uſual Evacuation of Blood, as the Hemerroids, or at the Noſtrils is impeded. Secondly, When Watery Blood is voided, occaſion'd by the Weakneſs of the Liver. The Third is, Blood mix'd with melancholly and burnt by reaſon of its being detaind in the Liver and Spleen is evacuated and ſhines. The Fourth and laſt, and that I am now treating of, is, when Blood and Excrements are mix'd together, and ſometimes alſo purulent Matter accompanies it, to the Patient's intolerable Pain.

Symptoms of a Dyſentery.The Diagnoſtick Signs of the Bloody-Flux, are, that the Sick Perſon is ſeized with unſufferable griping Pains in the Guts followed by frequent Stools, firſt of Whitiſh Matter, and afterwards of Blood and Slime mix'd together. Watching, Thirſting, loathing Food, and ſometimes attended by a Malignant Fever and all its diſmal Symptoms. If the Small Guts are affected, the Pain is vehement, like the pricking of Pins, becauſe they are of exquiſite Senſe: The Patient goes not to Stool preſently after the Pain, and when he does, is grievouſly tortur'd, and the Guts and Bowels ſeem to fall down. If the Great Guts are affected, the Pain is not ſo ſharp, and being ſeated toward the ſides of the Belly, is quickly followed by Stools; the
Blood ſwims on the top, or is a little mixd with the Excrements, and you may judge of the Humour cauſing this Diſeaſe, by the Colour of the Excrements, Age and Temperament of the Patient and the Seaſon of the Year.

There are Three degrees obſervable in a Dyſemery. The Symptoms of the firſt are Bloody and Slimy Stools. In the Second, the Slime is a Sign of Excoriation and in the third of an Exulceration. When the Guts are Excoriated, 'tis either the Cruſt that covers them, or part of their thick Tunicle, or at moſt the Caruncles, or inflamed Glandules of the Guts that is voided.

Prognoſtick Symptoms.A Dyſentery caus'd by black Choler is a dangerous Sign, if it be not Critical, becauſe the Ulcer grows Cancerous; be ſure therefore you make a right judgment between melancholly and congeal'd Blood. If loathing of Meat and a Fever accompany it, 'tis dangerous. If Pieces of Fleſh be voided in it, 'tis Deadly. Much Watching, great Thirſt, Black Bloody and Stinking Stool • , without a mixture of Humours, Hiccough, Cholerick Vomitings, Pains in the Liver and Midriff, are generally deadly Signs. If Choler and ſharp Diet is the Cauſe of this Diſeaſe, its eaſily cured; Salt Phlegm is worſe, becauſe ſticks longer in the Guts. If the becauſe it ſticks longer in the Guts. If the Bloody Flux happens to one troubled with a diſeaſed Spleen, or the Gout, its good, in the Opinion of Hippocrates, becauſe the Matter is ſent forth. But I rather take this for a Diarrhea than a Dyſentery.

Cauſes of the Bloody Flux.The Internal Cauſes of this Diſeaſe are ſharp and Ʋlcerating Humours. Yellow Green, and Black Choler; Salt Phlegm in the
Head created by Heat, or in the Belly by Putrefaction. which being brought to the Guts, and ſticking cloſe to them Ulcerates the Part. The ſharp Acid that irritates the Guts, provokes them to Contraction, aſſembles the Blood by vertue of its provocation, and corrodes the Orifices of the Blood Veſſels. This may proceed from the corrupted Matter in the Guts. But the cauſe of a Malignant, Epidemical, contagious Looſeneſs, ſuch as the Learned Sydenham diſcourſes of, as happening in the Years, 1669, 70, 71, 72, is a corrupt volatile Acid, not lodg'd in the Guts, but immediately reigning in the Blood, perverting its Texture, opening the Veſſels inſerted into the Guts and provoking them to Convulſive Contractions; from whence is derived a Malignant Fever, Griping and Bloody Stools: So tho' the previous excoriations may take place in benign Dyſenteries, there is no occaſion for them in the contagious Malignant ſort; it being a ſufficient Cauſe of bloody Stools, that the Coſtick Ferment is a Mortal Enemy to the Inteſtines, like Arſenick, that perpetually thwarts and provokes them to Convulſions; upon which, ſays that excellent Author, they ſqueeze out their Blood together with their Nutritious Juice, that they are not then in a capacity to receive; and which is taken by ſome for the Mucus or Snot of the Guts, whereas the large quantities that are voided, ſufficiently evince the contrary.

The External Cauſes, are all ſuch things as procreate ſharp and ill Humours, as Meats which ſoon putrify ill the Stomach, Fruits which are ſoon rotten, and all things unripe: The Air thus qualified; the Winter
co'd and dry, and the Spring very Wet and full of South Winds, cauſe Dyſenteries in Summer. Or if the Winter be Wet and full of South Winds, and a dry Spring, and the North Winds blow much; ſuch a Seaſon generally ſpeaking produces Bloody Fluxes. Sometimes the Air is infected and produces a Contagious and Epidemical Dyſentery, which is ſo infectious, that the Excrements of the Sick being caſt into a Bog-houſe, infect, all that ſit over it. To which may be added, the taking of Mercury, Coloquintida, Antimony, Lead, the courſe Pouder of an Adamant, Worms, &c. which vellicate the Guts and heap up ſharp Humours in them.

To Cure of the Bloody Flux.From what has been already ſaid, you may rationally infer, that Indications for Cure of a Dyſentery, are, to evacuate ſharp Humours, aſſwage Pain, Cleanſe, Conſolidate and Dry the Ʋlcers, Purify the Blood, ſeparate the preternatural Ferment and ſtop the Flux.

To diſcharge the Body of ſharp Humours you muſt Purge every Second, Third or Fourth Day, according to the Patient's Age and Strength, and the Seaſon of the Year. Rhubarb given in Pouder a Dram, a Dram and half, and two Drams is very uſual; but becauſe Pouders are apt to ſtick to the Guts and vex them, I better approve of it converted into a Potion, made of Liquoras, Raiſms of the Sun, Tamarinds and yellow Myrabolans boiled in Barley-Water, to Three or Four Ounces; which Liquor being ſtrained, infuſe in it a Dram of Rhubarb ſliced very thin; then add an Ounce of Syrup of Roſes Solutive, and you have a very good Medicine to evacuate ſharp Humours.

If the Dyſentery is accompanied with a Fever and Inflamation of the Bowels, open a Vein, let the Patient Bleed in proportion to his Strength. Sometimes vomiting is profitable, to repel the Humours, which fall from the Stomach to the Inteſtines, and therefore not to be omitted, eſpecially if the Patient is inclined to Vomit, for then Nature dictates the right way, and ought to be immitated, in disburdening a foul Stomach. Afterward you ought to give aſſwaging, mild and cleanſing Clyſters, and ſucceed them with Aſtringent Clyſters.

If the Ʋlcerss ſtand in need of cleanſing, add Centaury and Wormwood to the former Decoction, and to the ſtrained Liquor add Turpentine diſſolv • d in the Yolk of an Egg, and the Chymical Oil of Wax, of each one Dram. When there is more need of Binding and Glutinating Medicines, give Emplaſtick Clyſters, to cover the internal Superfices of the Guts, and preſerve thoſe Parts from the Gnawing of the Matter.

To cleanſe, give Goats Milk; to glutinate Cows Milk Chalybeated, which is proper to conſolidate and heal, to which you may add the Juice of Plantan, Syrup of Comfrey, Sugar of Roſes, Troches of Amber, and Rhaſis's white Troches. Let the Sick eat Rice boiled in Chalybiated Milk, or the Mucilage of Gum, Tragacanth and Arabick, drawn with Roſe or Plantan Water, the quantity of half a Dram in his Broath. To purify the Blood and ſeparate the preternatural Ferment, Goddards Drops are often ſucceſsful. And to compleat the Cure, the Body being throughly cleanſed you may uſe Aſtringent Decoctions and Narcoticks to ſtop the Flux.

And if this Courſe and theſe Medicines are ineffectual, as ſometimes to the Patient's diſappointment and extravagant Charge, they have been too often found; let the Sick try my Medicines, which have never yet failed to cure the Bloody Flux, in numerous Inſtances, of which I only give you Two Examples.

Mr. Alexander Carter, Taylor, dwelling in Swan-Yard, over againſt Somerſet-Houſe in the Strand, was ſorrowfully afflicted with the Bloody-Flux above two Years together, without any Intermiſſion, inſomuch that he had almoſt ruin'd himſelf in going from one Doctor to another, and yet was ſtill rather worſe than any thing better, till he came to me and made uſe of my Remedies, which cured him in a few Days, and now continues in as good Health, as ever he enjoyed in his Life. To the truth whereof he is ready to make Oath, if deſired.

Mr. Thomas Chiffinch, Carpenter, Aged Sixty odd Years, was Seven Years grieved with the Bloody Flux at certain Times; but the laſt Three Years had it conſtantly, and in ſo violent a manner as threatned him with inevitable Death, in the Opinion of all his Friends and Acquaintance; for he could find no Relief in all the means he uſed: But applying himſelf to me, and taking my Medicines, was cured in a ſhort time, and at a ſmall Charge; the truth of which immediate Cure, will be atteſted to any Perſon, that pleaſes to enquire either of Mr Clark, or the Patient himſelf, at Duglas's-Coffee Houſe in St. Martin's Lane, Weſtminſter.

Having now, I preſume, ſaid enough about the Cure of the Cholick in all its different kinds, and the other Diſeaſes that generally accompany it, ſufficient for the Inſtruction of the Induſtrious and Ingenious, and too much for the Envious Idle and Ignorant, I ſhould have concluded this Treatiſe, but becauſe I reſolve to publiſh ſeveral other Diſcourſes on other Diſeaſes, and that many People who have met with repeated Diſappointments in following other Mens Remedies, before my Books now under Hand can be Publiſh'd; for their ſakes as well as my own, I ſhall briefly ſhew, in a few Examples, in what other Diſeaſes as well as the Cholick, my Medicines have been wonderfully ſucceſsful, and alſo that the over curious or ſuſpicious may receive entire Satisfaction, by enquiring of the Perſons I have taken leave to Name, and the Places where they dwell, in the following brief Catalogue, which I ſhall begin with the Head-Ach.

Head-Ach and Vertigo. William Fletcher, of Engfield, in the Country of Middleſex, White-Smith, being grievouſly afflicted with the Megrim, Giddineſs and Swimming Pains in the Head, ſo that oftentimes he was in danger of falling down as he Work'd or Walk'd, which continued upon him for the long ſpace of Six Years, and uſing divers Medicines for his Cure, but without Succeſs; he applied to me, and I in letting him Blood in the inſide of one of his Noſtrils, and giving him a Medicine, he found immediate Relief, without any Pain or Trouble for above a Year; but afterwards finding a
Pain and Giddineſs, on the other ſide of his Head, and I letting him Blood in the Noſtril of that ſide, he was perfectly Cured of that Vexatious and Troubleſome Diſeaſe.

Head Ach.Mr. Samual Haines, Broad-Silk-Weaver, dwelling in Faſhon-ſtreet, in Spittle-Fields, London; was for the long ſpace of Twelve or Thirteen Years, violently afflicted with the Head-Ach, and tho' he induſtriouſly ſought Relief from other Hands, could find none, till he made uſe of my Remedies, and by them, the Almighty's Bleſſing interpoſing, was thoroughly cured.

Edward Harriſon, Leather Dreſſer, living with Sir Iſaack Shard, Knight, in Horſe-lye-Down, near Southwark, was ſorely afflicted with the Head-Ach at certain times, which return'd very often, and continued to his great Chief in this manner Six whole Years ſucceſſively, of which he could find no Cure, tho' he uſed variety of Medicines from no mean Profeſſors of Phyſick; but at laſt applying himſelf to me, was perfectly cured.

Margaret Thomas, Servant to the late Mrs. Jux, who was her Majeſty's Strower, and did then dwell in Little Scotland-Yard, adjoining to White-Hall, was grievouſly troubled with the Head-Ach for the ſpace of Two Years, and with other Female Diſtempers much longer, with which ſhe will acquaint any of her own Sex, that think-fit to enquire of her; but after the uſe of not a few Medicines preſcribed by other Practitioners
in Phyſick, without effect; ſhe was recovered from all her Diſeaſes by following my Advice, and the uſe of my Medicines, and continues in perfect Health to the preſent time.

William Watſon, late Servant to Mr. Welch, Vertigo. a Shoe-Maker, in Chancery Lane, London; was much troubled with a Vertigo, or Giddineſs of the Head, between Five and Six Years, and ſometimes ſo violently, that ſome thought it would terminate in a Appoplexy or Epilepſy, of which Diſeaſe he could find no Cure, till he applied himſelf to me, and by God's Bleſſing, and giving him Experienc'd proper Remedies, he was reſtored to Health.

Moſes Grant, late Servant to Mr. London, Perruke-Maker, in Channel Rowe, Weſtminſter, was Fourteen Years troubled with the Head-Ach, and Four Years laſt paſt, was afflicted with it in ſo grievous a manner and with ſuch intolerable Pain, without one Days intermiſſion; and making uſe of divers Medicines without Relief, he came to me, and I effectually cured him by giving him my Medicines in Six or Eight times, and he has continued well for a Year laſt paſt, as he aſſures me, excepting twice that he was ſlightly viſited with it, by too hard Drinking, which ſoon went off again, without the uſe of any means.

A Child of Mr. John Evans's, Frame-Work-Knitter, in Hand-Alley, in Biſhops-Gate-ſtreet, was ſo grievouſly afflicted with ſore-Eyes, occaſion'd by a Defluction of
Hot Rheum on thoſe tender Parts which continuing with great ſeverity above a Quarter of a Year, 'twas the general Opinion ſhe would be Blind; but her Father addreſſing himſelf to me, I perfectly cured his Childs Sore Eyes, and took away the Cauſe in Three or Four Days time, and left her as well as ever ſhe was in her Life.

The WormsMr. Robert Guinn, at the Sign of the Two Brewers, in White Lyon Yard, near Norton-Falgate, in the Pariſh of Stepney; for ſome Years paſt was ſo abundantly Peſter'd with Worms, that ſometimes they drop'd out of his Body as he went along the Streets, and at other times crept from him when he was in Bed. He was alſo afflicted with an Exceſſive Ravenous Appetite, and yet tho' he Eat as much as would have ſufficed Six or Eight Perſons, he received no Nouriſhment by his Food, but fell away, and was ſo waſted in his Fleſh, that he was little elſe than Skin and Bones. He had long ſought Relief from many, and variety of means, but all in vain, till he came to me, and through Mercy I cured him of all theſe complicated and uncommon Diſtempers, in about a Fortnights time; and has continued in a good ſtate of Health ever ſince.

The Son of Mr. John Carter, in George-Alley, in Coleman-ſtreet, London, who was about Two Years of Age, and terribly afflicted with Worms, and gnawing griping Pains, by taking my Remedies, voided above a Pint of Worms, was freed from his Pains, and has continued well ever ſince.
I could give you may other inſtances of Perſons of both Sexes, Young and Old, but I reſerve them for a particular Treatiſe of the Worms, that will immediately follow the publication of this Book.

Rheumatiſm and Gout.A Gentleman of conſiderable Quality, Lame with a Rheumatiſm and the Gout to ſuch a degree, that he dreaded the utter loſs of the uſe of his Limbs; but applying himſelf to me, I cured him of his Rheumatiſm, eas'd his Arthritick Pains, and ſo reſtor'd the uſe of his Limbs, that he is capable of attending his own Affairs: And tho' he will not allow his Name to be Printed, yet I have his leave to ſend any Perſon to him, who will confirm the Truth of what is here but privately divulg'd. To Name more Perſons whom I have cured of the Rheumatiſm, is wholly needleſs, ſince the Weekly Papers have from time to time, publiſh'd to many. And tho'. I don't pretend to m • ke a perfect Cure of the Gout, yet I hope I may be allowed to ſpeak truth, and ſay, That my Medicines never fail to give ſpeedy Eaſe in the moſt violent Pains attending that Diſeaſe.

The Stone & Gravel.Mr. William Cordwell, Frame-Work-Knitter, at the Sign of the Black-Boy, in Wheeler's-ſtreet, Spittle-Fields, being violently afflicted with Suppreſſion of Ʋrine, occaſion'd by the Stone, Gravel, and a concommitant Cholick, which had continued at certain Times for Three Years laſt paſt, and ſince Chriſtmas laſt in a more ſevere manner than ever; applied himſelf to me, and by the uſe of my Remedies aforenamed, voided ſeveral Stones and obtain'd a perfect Cure: And having paid me
for my Medicines to my own content, deſired alſo, that his Cure might be publiſh'd, that others labouring under the ſame Diſtemper, might receive Benefit by the ſame Hand and Means.

Francis-Wilks, Fevers. dwelling near the Sign of the Black-Horſe, in Blackman-ſtreet, hard by St. George's-Church, in Southwark, was ſeize Five Months with a Tertian Ague, and having taken great quantities of Jeſuit's Powder, or Peruvian Bark, and an incredible number of other Medicines, to no purpoſe; inſomuch that he ſeem'd to be on the Brink of the Grave, and his Circumſtances being but indifferent, I offer'd him his Cure Gratis, which I perform'd with great Expedition, and ſo effectually, that after the firſt Doſe of Phyſick I gave him, his Fit return'd no more, and the Patient enjoys his Health to this Day.

The great number of Patients I have cured of Fevers, under all Denominations, whether attended or unaccompanied with a Cold ſhaking Fit, which are vulgarly call'd Agues, will excuſe me from giving more Examples in this Diſeaſe, becauſe my Medicines, are ſo well known to give relief in Fevers, that to commend them by Teſtimonies in unceſſary waſte of time, ſince they recommend themſelves by their Innate Vertue; not becauſe they are Hot, not becauſe they are Cold, not becauſe they Cut and attenuate; but becauſe they have the peculiar vertue, to extinguiſh the hot fermenting Alkali, which is the Occaſional, Internal and Continent cauſe of Fevers, and that they may effect what they are deſign'd for, I vary them as I find Occaſion;
becauſe, vix ulla perpetua Ars Medicinalis recepit, ſcarce any of the Precepts of the Art of Phyſick are perpetual.

Coughs and Conſumptions.Mr. Thomas Adin, Weaver, dwelling in King's-Head-Yard, in Shore-Ditch, was long afflicted with a Conſumptive Cough, attended with all the diſmal Symptoms of approaching Death; but by the bleſſing of God, the Medicines I directed him to take, perfectly recovered him.

Spitting Blood. Mary, Wife of Mr. Richard Darling Barber, formerly dwelt in Burchen-Lane, near Lumbard ſtreet, London, was in Three Years time laſt paſt, twice cured by Medicines of a violent Cholick and Spitting Blood, and the laſt Spring was ſeized with a Hectick Fever, and all the dreadful Symptoms of an approaching Tabes or Conſumption, and was given over for a Dying Woman by all her Friends and Relations; but by Heaven Bleſſing the Medicines ſhe took of me, ſhe was reſtored to her former Health, as will be atteſted by more than Twenty Eye-Witneſſes of her unexpected Cure, as well as by the Patient her ſelf.

The French Diſeaſe.In the next place I could give many Examples of Perſons I have cured of both Sexes, of Gonorheas and the French Pox; but becauſe to give Examples in ſuch Caſes, would be a horrid breach of good Manners; I ſhall only recommend my Medicines as Safe and Certain in the Cure, and my ſelf for perfect Silence.

The Stone.The laſt Diſeaſe of which I ſhall give any Examples in this Book is the Stone, and ſhall begin in the well known Caſe of Mr. Richard Hurford, at the Sign of the New England Arms, near Ratliff-Croſs, who was Twelve Years afflicted with the Stone, but lately in a moſt violent manner, and having taken abundance of Medicines in hopes of Eaſe, but all in vain, I gave him my own Medicines experimentally adapted to the Cure of that Diſeaſe in his Caſe, which brought away an incredible number of Stones, and ſome of them as large as were capable of paſſing through the Ʋreters and can ſcarce be credited by any, but thoſe that have ſeen and handled them.

Mary, the Wife of Mr. Richard Pomfret, dwelling in Little Carter Lane, near the Swan Ale Houſe, was afflicted with the Stone and Gravel to that degree, that upon any agitation of the Body ſhe made Bloody Ʋrine, and after ſhe had had the Advice of ſeveral Doctors of Phyſick, but without ſucceſs; the firſt Remedy I gave her, put a ſtop to her Bloody Ʋrine, and brought away a prodigious Quantity of Gravel, by which means ſhe was Cured at a ſmall Charge, and in a very ſhort time.

Having thus plainly proved to the meaneſt Capacity, the efficacy of my Remedies the Sincerity of my Practice, and the Truth of the Examples of Perſons cured, inſomuch that they that are not blinded by partiality or byaſs'd by Intereſt, muſt be Maſters of a great deal of Sophiſtry, that will pretend to deny, contradict or oppoſe them. I ſhould now put an end to this brief Diſcourſe.

But having a little Paper to ſpare I ſhall employ it, in accommodating the Reader with the Vertues and Ʋſe of a bitter Medicament, which I invented, and call Tinctura Stomachicalis major, or the greater Stomachical Tincture.

Which is a Compoſition of all the Nobleſt Bitter Aromatick and Stomachical Specificks in the whole Materia Medica, and perfectly anſwers all Intentions accordingly. It enlivens and ſharpens a languid Appetite, expels Viſcous Humours; aſſiſts Fermentation and helps Digeſtion; Fortifies the Stomach and prevents Nauſeating and Loathing. It is Carminative, a great expeller of Wind out of the Stomach and Bowels; and as all bitter things are Medicinal againſt Worms, ſo this Tincture has an excellent faculty that way. If any Perſon has the misfortune to drink bad Wine, or to drink to exceſs; if he mingles ſome Drops of this Tincture in his Wine, it will rectify all Diſorders occaſion'd by hard Drinking, and prevent next Mornings Head-Achs, loathſome Vomitings, and menacing Surfeits, the uſual Attendants on Nocturnal Debauches. It's a good Remedy for Perſons newly deliver'd from a Fever, or any Chronical Diſtemper, becauſe it ſtrengthens the Craſis, or convenient mixture of Qualities. It's proper for Mariners to carry with them to Sea, and for thoſe that Travel by Land, becauſe it prevents ill accidents occaſion'd by Ill or Scanty Diet, change of Air, and Epidemical Infections. It far excels all other bitter Medicaments; it never offends the Eyes, or cauſes breakings out on the Skin, as generally all other Bitters do. It will keep good many Years, and may be taken in Wine, Ale, Tea, or Spring-Water,
from Thirty Drops to a Hundred, in the Morning, and at Four or Five of the Clock in the Afternoon, when People find occaſion for it, either to cure Diſeaſes, prevent them, or confirm one in a State of good Health, in which I have found my Tincture ſucceſsful in many Years Practice; being as pleaſant a Bitter as Art can contrive. One Ounce of Mine will make Three Ounces of any other Bitter, that is commonly expoſed to Sale. And that the Poor may receive Benefit by it, I will Sell it to ſuch as really are ſo, for Two Shillings the Ounce, and Twelve Pence the Half Ounce.
